name: Street Fighter V

reviews.review_text: Review from a new player:  I'm a total beginner at fighting games but after watching EVO this year I decided it was time to give them a shot. I decided on Street Fighter over other fighting games simply because it was the main event at EVO and seemed the most popular. I was a little skeptical after all the negative reviews but I'm glad I still decided to purchase the game. At the time of this review I've logged around 20 hours, purchased a used fight stick, and plan to continue playing which is more then most $60 games keep my attention for.  Pros- -Nice demonstrations explaining how the game works and terms new players might not be familiar with. -Character guides that help describe how you should use each character. Its nice for those not familiar with the Street Fighter franchise. -Story mode was enjoyable. Sometimes the screenplays were a little long but overall I enjoyed it. It started off super easy and became more difficult towards the end. I still haven‚Äôt been able to beat it on hard mode but provides a nice challenge and something to work towards. I also liked how it allowed you to play DLC characters to see how you liked them before purchasing. -Trials are fun and challenging. They provide more content to do for the person who is a completionist like myself. -Online replays are easy to find and watch. I enjoy watching the top tier players go at it. -Training mode is easy to use. -You earn a lot of fight money right away for completing single player features in the game. It is nice to be able to get a DLC character or two that you liked from the story mode for free. -Both my fight stick and xbox 360 controller worked with no problems. Reconfiguring buttons was very easy.  Natural- -Character story fell a little short. I like their attempt to further explain each characters story but each one is only 3-4 matches and way to easy, even for a complete beginner like myself. -Survival mode is redundant. I still find it fun but I just feel like its missing something.  Bad- -No VS. CPU mode or arcade mode. You can technically do this in training mode but being a fighting game you just expect this to be in the game. My guess is it'll be patched in eventually. -After the initial wave of fight money you get from single player, the fight money progression is extremely slow. I understand that Capcom needs to make money somewhere but its almost insulting at how little FM you earn after the initial wave. Personally, I'm at a point in my life where I can spend a little extra money on a character I want, but not everyone can do this (especially for a $60 title).  Thoughts on online play- -I've only logged about 30 or so matches but I find the match making to be pretty good. I realize I am going to be beat a lot online but I do feel like it matches me with people who I can feel like I at least have a shot against. It is pretty simple, you earn points if you win and lose points if you lose. It tries to pair you with someone that has similar amount of points as you. It would be pretty heart breaking if it just paired me against ‚Äúpros‚Äù all the time so I'm glad the game does not do that. Out of my matches, I have only had 1 match that was so laggy it was unplayable and maybe 1 that had periods of slight lag. One compliant is the amount of time it takes to search for an opponent. Sometimes I feel like I am waiting forever. I do think the fact that it auto uses your favorite character pretty annoying. For someone new like me that doesn‚Äôt have a main character, it forces me to log out of battle network to switch my favorite character every time I want to play someone new.  Overall I really enjoy the game and think it is a great fighter for someone looking to get into the genre. I would rate it a 9/10. All it is missing is VS CPU mode and arcade mode and I would think of the game as perfect.

Are you a tournament player?  If Yes: buy  If No: don't buy  This game was put out early for pro tour reasons. Anything that this game is missing doesn't really matter to tournament players. Only thing I dislike aobut this game is the long times are little long, but it's nothing to hate the game over.

If you want to play an amazing competitive fighting game, get this.  If you want to play a single player game, do not get this.

Let's get into it.  My first review was an obvious kneejerk reaction, as I liked the game a lot.  It released without a story mode. Said mode is coming very soon. Still, I would never, ever recommend a Street Fighter title at its release pricepoint of 60 dollars solely for the story mode, even if it released with one that provided 800 hours of content. Because it would be a convoluted, incomprehensible mess.  Let's be honest. The reason you're pondering whether or not to buy this game is so you can play Street Fighter with friends and/or people around the world.  Should you buy it if you're into that? It's a tough answer. The fighting is great, the combos are nice and simple but the game still has great depth. It looks pretty, it has crossplay with the PS4, Juri and Urien are gonna be in it, smug Asian-European waifu is playable, and the online can be a wonderful experience.  But it can also be so, soooo bad. If you're patient enough to deal with teleporting Rashids, if you want to train for tournaments, or if you have someone you really want to play it with, then yes, by all means buy it.  The problem is that SFV sells itself on its more basic roots, it tries to appeal to a more casual audience. If you are one of those casuals who's never played a fighter before, I would much rather recommend something like Brawlhalla or Killer Instinct, which offer much more content for a far less ridiculous asking price. KI has a singleplayer mode and the best training mode in any game besides Skullgirls (another game to recommend!).  These games give you vs. AI Single Fight modes. They give you attainable goals, they ask for much less in order to purchase the full gameplay experience. They give good netcode, in-game chat systems, and quick matches. These are all things SFV is severely lacking.  There is another type of casual, though. If you're the type of guy that tried to get into Ultra but found it too complicated, has played Mortal Kombat a few times, and has a copy of UMVC3 he plays with friends from time to time, this may be the game that gets you into Fighting Games for good, so long as you discover your inner Dhalsim and control the salt that arises from the game's many issues  Do I recommend it? I wish there was a maybe option. I like it, but it's crystal clear to me why others absolutely despise it. For now, it's recommended with some huge caveats.

+++ What's good +++  GAMEPLAY ¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø SFV caters to both newcomers and veterans. The core mechanics of the game promotes learning fundamentals and honing reads as opposed to godlike execution. As such, the entry barrier seem much lower than SFIV. But SFV still has crazy and long combos (I'm looking at you, Ibuki).  Characters are very diverse. Every character has their unique play style and each character can be played differently in the hands of different players. and the roster keeps growing every month approx!  MULTIPLAYER ¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø Despite what some may say, I had no problems with the online functionalities. Tho I understand this may be a subjective experience seeing as not everybody has the same ISP. I have personally not encountered any connectivity problems besides on launch week. I don't have a godlike internet, mine's just decent and I have no problems getting smooth matches every 15 seconds or so. and playing against PS4 users is perfectly fine as well. I might have had some few ticks every 5 rounds or so but the lag usually lasts a couple seconds.  FREE CONTENT ¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø Not exactly free, but SFV introduced a currency system called Fight Money (FM). You gain FM by playing the game and you can use it to buy several things such as characters, costumes, stages and whatnot. Most of the content are DLCs, which means you can basically get the DLCs for free. Altho some items are considered premium, which can only be bought with real currency. Of course, every extra content can also be bought with real money in case you want to avoid grinding for FM.  CONSTANTLY EVOLVING ¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø Capcom stated that they will continuously maintain and improve on this game to ensure it will keep growing. This includes additional characters, costumes, stages and a balance patch every year (or so they say) Thus far, it's seems that they are successfully delivering their promise. Their scheduling may need some work seeing as they've had a bit of communication issues with the fanbase. Nevertheless, it's always nice for a company to stay active on the development of a game.   --- What's bad ---  STORY ¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø It's Street Fighter. The franchise never had AAA level story. The newly released Cinematic Story Mode is decent because you get to see your favourite characters fleshed out in cutscenes that are very well animated (to my surprise). But lore-wise, it's a pretty generic 'evil dude tries to conquer the world and the good guys tries to stop him'. No character development or plot-twist or anything impressive. Don't expect anything Blazblue level. (Cutscenes are eye candy tho, very pretty)  GRAPHICS CLIPPING ¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø Lots of characters have some form of clipping in their models, especially the hair. It's not even subtle, you can clearly see Ken's hair going through his shoulder or Birdie's chain going through his necklace. Nothing really drastic but it's uncommon to leave so many graphics eye sore in our current gen standard.  SURVIVAL ¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø A game mode that gives you FM and character colors, but it's annoying to play because AI are either braindead stupid or they legit read your inputs and counter everything you do. Very tedious experience and annoying as well.  FM GRINDING ¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø You only get 50 FM per online VICTORY (doesn't include Battle Lounge, which is the friendly lobbies you create between friends and whatnot) To put things in perspective, a character costs 100 000 FM, a costume 40 000 FM, a new stage 70 000 FM. Basically everything is in the thousands. Their are other ways of getting FM such as completing character trials and story mode, but those are one time things. Afterwards, FM are pretty hard to come by.   Capcom did say they were gonna include a system called Daily Challenges that would reward players with FM if they perform certain requirements, altho we have no infos about what are the requirements or the amount of the rewards.   Ok I got lazy, I could've probably squeezed in a few more points in the What's Bad section but honestly, this game is worth it. Many people have complained about the game being unfinished and that's understandable. But this isn't one of those games that feels incomplete and is going to stay this way. SFV is constantly being improved and we've seen this happen with the slew of new content and updates. That's why I am recommending this game. It'll be worth it in the long run.

New account, had to get this on Steam. Says 6 hrs of play, that's going to change quick. I have sunk more hours into this game then Skyrim, BL2, Fallout4, Witcher 3, or Dark Souls 1&2 ( 3 blows donkey balls [4 games deep FromSoft still doesn't understand player latency]) and I've laughed, I've cried, I've taunted, I've teabagged, I've been stunned, I've been cheated of victory, I've ate a full Chun-li CA, I've gone to the bar during Devour-our, I've slipped on some banana peels, I've been utterly humiliated by a Dirty Dhal, I've eaten more SHORYUKENS!!!! from online Kens than you could wave a stick at, I've had some great meaties and been mixed up by some of the best set-ups. All in all, I hate to love this game. This game, fighting games in general, I suppose, has a certain rage inducing vomit build up in your goiter and trust me, the first time you play against a Mika--YOU'LL KNOW what I mean. The best part about it is I have no one to blame but myself. Sure, you get those laggy match-ups sometimes where the character is on the other side of the screen and next thing you know you're eating a full jump-in combo, but after that--it's up to you. Do you want to be the best, like no one ever was? Then you have to train, not only your body, but your spirit and mind to withstand the onslaught of failures that will come. I have always been afraid to really get into fighting games because I thought I would never be good. That truth still holds today. Now, I can pull off an anti-air here and there and still get cannon spiked in the FACE when they land. That is exactly why I love this game though. Sure you could moan and say, 'Oh but a 3-frame invincible move isn't FAIR!' Well guess what? Life's not fair, get over it, hold back AND CRUSH COUNTER THAT SKRUB!!!!!
This is the kinda game I might play.

An extremly solid fighting game, 16 extremly well balanced characters, best netcode of any fighting game when you have a good connection, fluid combat, new characters are interesting, old characters are redesigned to feel like new.  Overall 9/10, really is a must-buy if you are even a minor fan of fighting games.

It's my favorite fighting game. It's pretty easy to get by as a beginner and button mash, but once you get past that there's a lot of depth to the fighting experience. I'll admit Capcom dropped the ball by releasing this game unfinished (yet still asking full AAA price) but most of the stuff that needs work is with the User Interface. There's no doubt the game still needs polish, but Capcom has expressed that they hear the community and plan on supporting this game for years to come. The competitive scene is alive and well, and still growing. All of the non-casuals are training hard as we speak, so don't wait until its too late to git gud!

The greatest 1v1 PVP experience out there by far. The game is fun, balanced, simple in the execution of tecnique yet endlessly deep in interaction between players. Street Fighter has gotten more streamlined with every iteration and Street fighter 5 continues this trend. Whether your playing with friends or online theres always fun to be had, and something new to learn about your opponents.  I want to address 2 of the common criticisms of the game and how the game is actually comparitively robust in these 2 areas. The DLC model and the Single Player content.   The game has pretty much adopted letter for letter the same model as League of Legends, all gameplay related content can be purchased with in game currency earned over time. Looking at League of Legends average match time of 37 minutes and 100 IP (its ingame currency) earned in that time it would take 2,886 minutes to earn enough currency for 1 Champion. In street fighter at an average of 45 seconds per round, 2 rounds per game, and 50 points per win it would take 3000 minutes. That doesnt account for the bonus xp earned from weekly quests ( land a throw 10 times or some such thing) for 500 - 1000 points a piece, bonus points for account and character rank ups, and the 100k+ to be earned per completion of each of the sigle player modes in each difficulty. Long story short its more than a fair time sink compared to other games that give you the option to purchase new content or unlock it.  Single Player compared to any PVP focused game gives you plenty to do theres 2 versions of story mode one of which has 2 difficulties and a survival which has 5 difficulties. Story took me about 2 days to complete, I havent run through survival yet but i wager that will take longer than the 2 story modes combined. That being said Not Paladins, not Overwatch, not League of Legends, Not Dota 2, or most other PvP based games have any single player of any sort and are judged solely on the depth and fun offered in their gameplay.   I'm 100% satisfied with what I got from this game and look forward to what season 2 has to offer.
For all the issues with it, it's still easily the best Street Fighter on PC, and one of the better Street Fighter games made to actually play competitively.

Street Fighter V had a rough start. Released back in february 2016, the game shipped in a bare state (To put it mildly). The reason for this was the Capcom Pro Tour, which was going to start just a couple of weeks after the game's initial release. The Capcom Pro Tour is a set of tournaments that is being held throughout the year, where players around the world get to earn points for their placings in these tournaments. The Pro Tour culminates in the Capcom Cup which is set to take place at the end of the year, this is where the top ranking players from Pro Tour dukes it out to crown the champion. This ended up hurting sales alot, but the tournament participation was blooming. Whether Capcom was doing the right thing by releasing the game in an unfinished state in favor of the Pro Tour is a debate of it's own.  The past is in the past, and what matters is what you get today. Over the year, the game's content has expanded immensely. The game's current state, is what it should have been shipped with. The game's roster consists of 16 characters, with 4 of them being newcomers to the series. An additional 6 characters can be bought either by the game's in-game currency (Fight Money) or with real money. There might be less characters in the roster than previous titles offer, but the characters feels more unique than ever before with the introduction of V-skill and V-trigger (moves and abilities unique to each character), which you'll get to know more about in the game's tutorial.  There is plenty of single-player content available to this otherwise multi-player focused game. There is a tutorial where you get to learn the basics of the game's mechanics. There is a story mode, which consists of bite-sized backstories for each character. And a more fleshed out main story, with in-game cutscenes and a ridiculous plot (Which shouldn't surprise anyone, it is a fighting game after all). If you want to learn the ropes with a specific character, the trials has returned, with 10 of them for each character. There is also the mandatory training mode, with recording and playback, which allows you to experiment with different scenarios and setups. Capcom has also introduced daily and weekly challenges, which earns you fight money. The challenges feels lazy for the most part, but earns you a quick buck in terms of fight money. There is also the horrible survival mode, which unfortunately is good source of earning Fight Money and colors for each character within the game, the latter is optional though since the colors has been made available lately via the shop aswell.  When it comes to netplay, Street Fighter V shines. It relies on a rollback netcode, which grants a lot less input latency when playing online. This can however result in your opponent teleporting around the screen if the connection is poor. But overall, this is a great improvement. There is ranked play where players can earn or lose points to compete on the leaderboards, and also a casual mode which functions just like ranked play but without the stress of losing/earning points. Players can also create private or public fight lobbies, for up to 8 players. Street Fighter V also supports cross-platform play, which enables you to face off against players on the Playstation 4 aswell. Cross-platform is a great thing, because it expands the player pool by a great deal, especially for the PC-players since the vast majority of players reside on the Playstation 4-version of Street Fighter V (1.2m total sales at this point, where roughly 200k of those are the PC-version).  Street Fighter V is great for newcomers to the series and fighting games in general. The bar for executing combos is alot lower than the previous titles. While this enables most players to dish out plenty of damage when the opportunity arises, it also takes away a bit from the fullfillment of actually performing the combos. As the combos get's easier, the game relies more on mastering movement and spacing.  Since I have spent the majority of my time with the game on PS4 (About 600~700 hours) and only just recently bought the game for PC, I can allready say that the PC-version is technically superior in many ways (As one should expect). The game is still locked at 60fps, which for competetive reasons makes sense. But the PS4 version tends to dip on certain stages, which just doesn't occur on the PC-version assuming you have a capable computer. Both versions have a small amount of input-lag (the time it takes for your actions to register on the screen), which can be reduced on PC by turning off VSYNC. However, most players will not notice anyways and as the tournament standard is still the PS4-version, you re probably better off leaving it on.  There is also a very healthy mod-community for Street Fighter V, with a lot of custom skins and models to download for each character. If you want Reinhardt to perform a Double Lariat on Tracer, the world is your oyster.  Back in february, Street Fighter V was a hard sell - but now it is quite the opposite. And with rumours of a new season of characters to be announced at the upcoming Capcom Cup, there has never been a better time to buy in.
Hope to have faster bug fix and controller fix, still nominated.

Street Fighter V.   Pros:  Easy to pick up and learn, but it still makes you work to get to the top.  A very nice and unique soundtrack for each character, for example F.A.N.G he has a very well suited soundtrack for his character.  Impressive visuals on critical arts and specials.  Character models look much more 'Human' unlike Street Fighter 4.  Free DLC Characters, you can earn 40000 points in no time, really no reason for moaning. If you're playing this game enough it should be no problem.  Voice acting on point as always such as M. BISON!   Cons:  I really do hate the ranking system in this game, if you are mid-low level you will be mostly be facing Super Silver to plat, which means you are not ranking up or down, you are just getting your ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• beat every time. This is gonna turn away casuals for sure.  The price of this game to me is too much, ¬£44 is a bit steep if your just gonna be learning for 100+ hours to beat them   Thats all I can do for cons.   Summary: Sure you could say this game is 'unfinished' but what do you buy Street Fighter for, to play solo offline and arcade? No.   I have encounterd no bugs or glitches with the game either. Anyway, if you like the Street Fighter Series you are gonna love this game either way.

Yo, If you wanna go dumb, I'll go dumb with you. You have to do WORK and don't even think about taking the credit. My Birdie, outta control, Laura, outta control and that Eggnog, definitely outta control. You wanna pick this game up.

Great fighting system! It's better than Alpha 3, but not quite as technical and smooth as Third Strike's fighting system. As we all know, this game is not complete and is quite expensive for an Early-Access-online only game. The Net-code is horrible and will randomly disconnect you from the server (there are no rewards in offline play). Currently, the game offers poor optimization, and story mode is currently underwhelming . This game seems rushed and I doubt it will be completely fixed by the end of the year. If you're a hardcore SF fan, this will be fun in short bursts. If you're not a hardcore fan, this won't be the SF to win you over unfortunately. When this game is finally complete I wonder how much all the dlc will cost? I am aware that fight money is supposed to allow you to buy all furture DLC characters, but, I don't know. I smell a foul smell coming from that shop...

Bought it after the update during the Summer-Sale and compared to other fighting games, it really isn't bad at all. The Gameplay is what you'd expect from a SF-Game, Story mode is a nice little extra, graphics are amazing, netcode has been fine so far, some laggy games every once in a while, but that's it. There is a pretty cool tutorial, which can really help anyone who is new to fighting games. I personally don't like the inclusion of the fight money, but i guess it's a way to keep people motivated. And if you REALLY want to play with all the characters you can always buy the DLC, but that's a different story. Only other complaint is, that some of the alternate costumes are 3.99 each, even if you've bought the season pass, keep that in mind, even though it doesn't really affect the game.   Overall, it is one of the better fighting games. Would recommend!

TL;DR:  -is the game unfinished? pretty much yeah  -is it fun? pretty much yeah  -but it's not worth $60? pretty much yeah   legit tho the game is fun but flawed I'm a street fighter fanboy so i still like it, characters are implemented well, very detailed actually in terms of references to previous games and including elements to make them feel like they always have  As far as fighting specifically, it's super smooth, and the gameplay is solid, typical street fighter stuff, v-trigger is great But you are pretty much buying it for multiplayer, because until they release story mode later this month, there's not a whole lot to do  The game isn't worth the full sixty if you are not into fighting games, but if you are then you are pretty much good to go, because multiplayer is all you really need
most balanced sf ever

This is a tough game to judge from a review. Being a fan of street fighter ever since street fighter 2 came out when I was in grade school I wish I could say this is a 10/10 game.   Unfortunately it is not.  The single player content is sorely lacking, the character story mode is a joke when it comes to the actual fighting part. You get one round fights that my toddler can beat simply by button mashing. The biggest let down to me is no arcade mode like the previous games. Vs mode can only be played locally against another player.  The online part of this game is very good and addicting though. Playing with a stick the gameplay is amazing. I'm not a huge fan of the current roster of fighters, or how some of the orginal fighters have been changed, but I'm sure that will be improved in the coming years as this game grows.   As it stand if your looking for a good fighting game to play online this game is great, if your expecting that great experience to also include the content for single player stick with ultra 4.  Right now this game to me is a 7/10 that hopefully will raise higher in the future as capcom continues to improve this game.

The introduction of the cinematic story and daily challenges are welcome additions, although DLC is over priced, so use your Fight Money wisely ü§î

The definitive fighting game experience. A must-have for any fighting game fan. While imarred at launch with many significant issues, it has been steadily moving forward in fixing them, adding new characters, stages, and giving us some of the best e-sports out there in the form of Capcom Cup 2016. Single player content still isn't quite right, although there's been a lot of it added, but this game is all about competitive play, and as far as fighting games go, this is the one everyone should know.
Sometimes lags bad, fun game, decent balance, grind a bit, future updates to come.

I WOULD rate this neutral if I could but I can't. SFV is an incomplete Fighting Game that takes from P2W games by making characters locked behind a paywall. The paywall can be accessed by ingame currency though... 100,000 of that currency that is, which can be earned by winning 2,000 matches or completing the terrible story mode. There's no arcade mode, and it's replacement, survival mode, is awful. Out of ALL these reasons NOT to buy the game, why do I recomend it? Because it's fun as hell! I love how fluid the controls are! I'd say, buy this game during a sale.  Edit: There's now an actual story mode and it's pretty good! It gives you 30,000 of the currency which still isn't enough to get a character. I guess that means they got rid of one of the cons of this game, being: a terrible story mode

I've played street fighter since I was a kid. Played all the alpha games. Played the 3d street fighter game, played capcom vs snk, street fighter x tekken, ALL of them. Side scrolloer fighting games are my cup of tea. I LOVE the street fighter series, although I always kind of dogged them for NEVER changing their timing and range. Before you get into the advanced techniques of fighter games (Poking strategy, cross ups, bait tactics, chip damage, high-low combos, frame reversals) you have 2 things. Timing and range. For 20 years timing and range has not changed on street fighter even though the graphics and fps has gotten better most changes was strictly cosmetic.........And here comes street fighter V. Characters such as Nash and Vega's special moves input has changed....and yes...timing and range have changed as well. Great job Capcom. Street fighter is elite once again. I highly recomend this game!!!!!!!

Now that all the crucial components promised are already out, this is the HONEST review.  GRAPHICS +1 light rendering, as is expected from Unreal Engine 4, currently the best techniques in the industry +1 character models +1 high quality textures +1 interface is easy to use -1 hair and clothes meshes often clip -1 some stages have low texture quality -1 some background NPCs animate in lower FPS than   SOUND +1 less focus on electronic/synthesized music and more actual instruments used +1 more variety and uniqueness while still staying true to character(ie. Guile's prog-rock/jazz arrange) +1 music pumps people up, from intro, to menu, to character themes +1 Japanese dub has more hits than misses -1 certain stage-specific themes are trash tier -1 English dub has more misses than hits. Too much improv by VAs when compared to Japanese  BASE GAMEPLAY SYSTEM +1 quite balanced for a game that skipped arcade release +1 each character has more distinct playstyles to one another, compared to previous games(Ryu and Ken is now truly night and day) +1 more lenient execution frametime and focus on footsies allow for fights on a more fundamental level while reducing physical restraints, although mastering the system is still not easy. +1 FADC system has been replaced by V-trigger system, making excessive offense less safe.  -1 game has seemingly dev-implemented minus-8 frames of lag, which makes certain characters frustrating to use(ie. Zangief)  NETWORK PLAY *needs mentioning* game deals with lag not by increasing time between input and on-screen execution(SFIV), but by warping the situation back to when it was executed. Some prefer it, some are indifferent, others hated it. If your connection is good, chances are you won't see it. Too neutral to be given or deduced points for.  +1 it works, to an extent +1 Ranking system starts easy, but requires more points to reach higher leagues, and losing as higher league against lower league makes you lose a lot of point. Keeping rankings legit with less frauds and one-trick ponies while giving less room for boosters to breeze their way up... if there isn't another way to cheat it. -1 overall server functions are still flawed as of this writing. Errors often occur after matches end; most of the time, your points will be correctly added or deducted later, but sometimes it doesn't register.   even basic connectivity is still compromised during long survival modes, as many people still struggle to finish Survival mode without disconnecting and having to restart(this is important because Survival mode needs to be played while online to obtain in-game money for unlocks)  lastly, the statistics only half works. You need to depend on external sites like vleague.pro for extra data crunching, which is a shame.  -1 match filtering options are too small, and some of them do not even work. 5 bar connections may sometimes feel like 3, depending on your location and ISP.  -1 Rage Quitting, or the act of quitting the game/disconnecting/unplugging the Ethernet cable shortly after 'KO' is announced to prevent the game from properly registering your loss and deducting your points, is still rampant. The current punishment system implemented failed to prevent this trend as it is still too lenient and certain regions are filled with people who do this on instinct.  OTHERS +1 essential game components such as characters and stages are all unlockable by in-game money alone, which can be obtained by finishing the single-player contents or fulfilling certain requirements. The only content locked with real money so far are 'premium' costumes for each character. Just be careful not to spend your Fight Money too much on colors and titles  +1 Training mode is the most in-depth it has ever been in a Street Fighter game. Plenty of options to customize your training setup needs and one-button position resets. You can tell that the professional players had a lot of input in this one.   +2 arcade mode doesn't exist, but they are now streamlined into 'Survival mode', 'Character Story' and 'General Story'. You will fight a bunch of CPU characters in all of these modes, although Survival focuses solely on fighting, and the story modes only give 1-round matches while unveiling the drama. These in themselves are good things, however...  -1 Survival mode is very grind heavy. While common CPU difficulty spikes are usual stuff for fighting games, they get ridiculously cheap in later stages on Normal and above. You will not learn anything useful for fighting human opponents as defeating them requires you to be cheap as well.  And while completing Survival mode unlocks new alternate colors for free, you will have to do this for EVERY costume set(DEFAULT, STORY and PREMIUM), including the costumes you paid with real money.  -1 character stories and general story are poorly written. The Shadow Falls story had its moments, but it clashed with too many plotlines established by previous games. Some things also do not make sense, even considering SF's comical nature. Expect upsets if you want to see longtime characters getting their shining moment here.  -1 stage transitions; which shows your characters transitioning from one stage to another, or crushing into background objects after a round defeat, is still limited to the China stage. They promised us this, yet fail to deliver them all despite development screenshots and data minings showed they had all this set up for other stages too, yet still nothing after over 4 months.  TECHNICALITIES +1 game is optimized well enough to be played either with a cheap laptop sporting modern integrated Intel GPU to the big boys using high end stuff -1 high amount of animation and richer movements demand more CPU power. You may need CPUs that are better than 2-core/4-thread low-end CPUs for Network play. -1 certain issues with resolution may cause minimal stutter and lag at resolutions lower than 1080p on certain systems. -1 after more than 4 months, still no Direct Input support, requiring you to use third party software to use anything other than the X Box controller -1 keyboard controls are still not fully customizable  SCORE SUM = 18/34 (>50%, RECOMMENDED, with caution)  Summary: The game has good stuff, and some of its bad stuff can be fixed using external means, but those coming from SFIV series and wanted more of THAT, those expecting deeper storylines, or people that have very low patience for online play issues may want to avoid this.   Regardless, when the game drops below 30 US dollars, its unconditionally recommended for all of you.
Awesome fighting game. The people whinging about the content...it will come. The actual fighting mechanics and art style is brilliant. When did reviewing ever come down to qantity > quality

If I had written this review a while ago, I would say to wait to purchase SFV, but now the game is genuinely solid. It still needs some love in one area, which is connectivity, but i think it might be my net. Ive got good ping in most games but i think this game just requires minimal packet loss and good bitrate to function right online.  Overall, the gameplay itself is great. The game focuses heavily on mind games, player focus, frame traps, footsies (sometimes) and anti airs, and execution has been reduced from SF4. I can play the entire cast, and probably a fifth of them reliably, which is much better than what i could say about SF4, although some argue the easier execution makes the game worse, i disagree. there is still enough complication and complexity to make it fun and engaging. Character cast is good and plays diversely different, stages look nice, and the game has a lot of 'momentum' to its play. Great new stuff is also featured, such as vskills, vtriggers, crush counters and the rest. This is all terminology, and I suggest reading up on what these are on a wiki or a guide or something going in. Youll want to know things like that and others, such as 'frame advantage.'  Other than the previously mentioned connection problems I face, some people think the DLC policy is pretty bad, and it is, but it is possible to unlock the important things fairly easily just by playing, every matchmaking game you win you get 50 'fight money,' every time you level up a character you get 1000 FM, you can get 6000-10,000 FM weekly doing challenges, winning survival on each difficulty for the first time on each character also grants you fairly large chunks of FM. Basically, play everything the game has to offer and characters suddenly seem easy enough to just unlock, with some patience.  I reccomend if you want a good fighting game to play against others with.

Good old Street Fighter... The franchise that made fighting games into what they are today. After a really rocky launch, Street Fighter V is shaping up to be pretty good in the long run. It still has its fair share of problems though.  The core gameplay of the game is great. It very much feels like a slower, slightly watered down Third Strike, yet faster at times than 4. Smart play is rewarded, such as good reads, out thinking your opponent, applying pressure, mix-ups, and other various shenanigans to victory. Defensive play is still a viable tactic, it's just a bit harder to do with how offense heavy the game is.  Online play is a bit hit and miss. Matches can range from feeling like fast fluid offline versus, to totally annoying teleporting laggy crap. Luckily, the lag can be avoided for the most part. Searching for 4-5 bar connection opponents and forwarding the proper ports can minimize the lag as much as possible. Also, play wired, do not play on wi-fi. For new players, I suggest starting with casual instead of playing ranked right away. Helps to get a feel of how to play against people.  Performance might not be perfect for everyone. Your mileage might vary in that regard, much like many games. The game generally runs fine with almost no frame drops. For me personally, I had some driver crashing and frame drop issues right away. Turns out the game hated the overclock on my graphics card and the driver version. Rolled back on the driver and toned down the clocks a bit, now there's no issues and it runs smooth as butter.  As for the DLC practices... it's not bad, but I wouldn't say it's overly great either. You can buy DLC with in-game money, known as Fight Money. Characters cost 100,000 Fight Money, story costumes for 40,000, stages from 40,000-70,000, and colours 11 and up for 2000-10,000. Premium costumes cost $4 each (a little expensive for a skin basiccaly, I know) and to pay for a character would be $6. The season pass is available, which nets you all 6 of the DLC characters and their premium costumes at a discount (perfect for folks that don't want to grind all money and have everything). That is only for season one however. The first 400,000 Fight Money is earned relatively quickly and easy, if you are decent at learning combos and have some patience to sit through easy survival with the entire cast.   On the topic of survival... here comes the ugly parts of the game. If you want colours 3-10 for your character and/or costume, you need to do survival! Over and over and over again. Easy is trivial, but nets you some fight money and a whopping one colour. Normal nets you more fight money, colours, but can be long, repetitive and boring, especially when the AI decides to go crazy on you then you have to restart. From the beginning, do it all over again! Colour bundles are now available to buy with fight money.  On to my final gripe. If you want to play on controller or arcade stick, you either have to use one that is xinput compatable or use an xinput wrapper that will cause button lag. As far as I know, dinput has yet to be supported. This is a non-issue for people that play using xbox controllers/sticks, keyboard, or PS3/4 controllers (running DS4windows, SCP, or the like).   All in all, I recommend the game. Especially for fighting game fans such as myself. There's no arcade mode as of yet, a story mode was added recently, and the online is mostly the meat of the game. So that might deter some people. For the casual fans and players, I also recommend it if you want to get into fighters and get better. Pick it up while it's on sale, unless you must have it right now.

Do you want a feature complete game? Do not buy this. Do you want a fighting game? You might want to consider reading more before buying. And please make sure to read more reviews before deciding whether to buy this! Use this as a second opinion!  This game is not feature complete. There is no real story mode; no real singleplayer. There are no lobbies (there is something called a battle lounge, but its 1 on 1). There is no challenge system and while I have not played survival, its pretty quick and lame from what I have read. All this stuff is coming in the free March update. The games mandatory tutorial does not tell you much aside from that your fists can punch, you can throw out a fireball if you are Ryu, your legs can move and kick, and you can block stuff. The tutorial, however, fails to mention more crucial things: did you know you can quick recover from a knockdown into a roll by double tapping left when you hit the ground? You can also quick rise by double tapping down. They acknowledge throw breaks, but don't tell you how to do them, which might seem like its common sense to most people but someone brand new to the series wouldn't get it. The tutorial overall is just very vague for a game that is trying to bring new blood into a niche genre.  As a fighting game, I'm enjoying this. I think right now its a solid experience if you want to hop in, train, and fight live players. I play them pretty casually, so I'm no expert at the systems present, but it does change quite a bit from the last title I spent time with (SFIV). The new Variable Gauge system creates more identity to the characters, as activating your V-Trigger will alter your moveset, giving them new properties or creating new moves entirely. Every character now has a V-Reversal while allows them to escape pressure through a knockdown as well as a V-Skill that alows characters to dissipate projectiles or other perks unique to the character. The Variable Gauge system changes a lot from the last system, but people who have played the Alpha series or Third Strike might feel right at home with it.  Links and execution in this game also feels much easier than 4, making it a breeze to get in and start practicing your bread and butters until your thumb or wrist hurts. This also means this game is very accessible to new fighting game players, so long as they take the neccessary steps to get outside information, have a proper mindset, and a willingness to learn from their mistakes.  Overall, I think Street Fighter V can only get better from here on. At $60, its a very tough decision for a lot of people. If you wanted a feature complete game, you should wait until March or maybe April at the latest before jumping into the fray. If you know all this, and don't care, you have a fighting game that is very solid when the servers aren't acting funny. Here is hoping Capcom keeps it up and makes this game fantastic, because it has the potential to survive for a really long time if they play their cards right.

Great core gameplay, but not without its faults. If you are interested in single player game modes then I would suggest holding off on purchasing this game until that content arrives, but if you are mostly interested in online then you would find a lot of enjoyment with this game. With that said, there are still some things to consider.  The biggest issue in my opinion is that this game (A PC and PS4 exclusive) lacks Direct input support on PC. This means that all of your PS4 arcade sticks won't work on this version of the game, you will need a stick that has X input (360 stick) or use third party software to get your direct input stick to work. Doesn't sound like a huge issue, but I have experienced noticeable input lag with using anything but Joytokey. Maybe your system will work better with the some software over others, I don't know, there are several of these sofwares but Direct input support has been promised on launch day by a Capcom representative and they haven't mentioned it since. For all the players who like to play 2D Fighters on keyboard, there is no key mapping, so you're stuck with the default mapping.  The next issue I'd like to mention is Ragequitting. Capcom's solution to ragequitting is laughable at best. These types of games will always have ragequitters and many games have implemented very capable systems to handle the issue, but Capcom's solution has taken too long to be implemented and has the posibility of locking out people who genuinely disconnect from the servers for up to two hours.  Again, the gameplay is solid, but if Capcom would just do a better job communicating with the community about the issues in the game and when we can expect certain things to be fixed instead of constantly giving us the silent treatment I think the game would be doing a lot better.

Online issues appear to have been resolved and 9 times out of 10 runs flawlessly. Sadly the game is lacking in single player content. Personally this doesn't bother me much as additional offline modes and options are being added in March for free. Currently the game only supports Xinput (Xbox360/XboxOne controllers/sticks). Any devices utilizing direct input (PS3/PS4 sticks and controllers) are NOT detected by the game. This too is being patched in down the road at no additional cost. This is an an inconvenience for sure, but there are programs that will allow you to map your direct input devices in the meantime. All in all, the core game is very solid and worth the cost of admission if you plan on playing competitively. Casuals may want to hold off until more single player content is available

An incredible new entry in the Street Fighter Series shows its latest entry as both the most accessible and most compellingly competitive iteration yet: Street Fighter V is a charming, addicting, beautiful, and engaging online fighting game made for the latest generation - of consoles and of players both. Its incredibly diverse cast offers toolsets for every playstyle from defensive and calculating to viciously aggressive. The game is strategically deep and deeply rewarding; a variety of modes offer offline ways for players to learn the game, and it boasts some of the best online netcode yet (only to be rivaled by GGPO-netcode games). Pay no mind to the ant-minded, short-sighted negative reviews about launch day problems - this is the world's premiere fighting game that boasts the absolute best the entire genre has to offer you, and it is going to get better and better for free for years to come. Get on the streets.

Street Fighter V is a story of brilliant ideas and intentions brought down by consistent fumbling that defies belief.  The premise of SFV is simple, you take the established Street Fighter gameplay and simplify it in a way that only makes the game more enjoyable for new and old players alike. You take the old capcom fighting game business model of 'release a new edition every 2 years' and you throw it out the window because everybody hated it, replacing it instead with a one box one purchase product with DLC that can be unlocked for free by playing the game, honestly one of the most commendable and customer friendly decisions ever made by a video game company.  Issues arise when you outsource development to incompetent people in order to rush the game out ahead of schedule causing the netcode to be unreliable and choppy and full of client desync, matchmaking to be slow, and the lobby system to be borderline unusable. Compounded by failure to add directinput controller support for over nine months, dinput meaning literally anything that doesn't run on xbox software, a platform this game isn't even available on. Insult added to injury when they release a 'security update' which installs what can only be described as a rootkit virus on your pc in order to detect people unlocking things in the game they shouldn't have access to, which was later rolled back after public outrage.  Capcom have shot themselves in the foot with such aggressive frequency that it's starting to look like they're following up on purpose in order to pass off the first incident as intentional. It's a real shame, because technical issues aside, Street Fighter V is the best game in its genre. Highly recommended if you like fighting games and are willing to look past these few problems.          YouTube‚Ñ¢ Video:  Evo moment #37
Good but 4 is the better game
Season 2 boys!

Been playing for a week now, up to about 18 hours, and I have no problem giving this a thumbs up.  -The characters are diverse (and by that I mean F*** Birdie). -The stages are better than SF4 (and by that I mean SFxT stages). -The matchups are balanced (unless you lose). -The mechanics are easy to learn (and by that I mean it's not an Arc System Works Game). -The connectivity is great (and by that I mean the connectivity of people on YOUR continent). -The actual 'feel' of the game is one of the best fighting game experiences I've seen in a long while (and by that I mean it's one of the best fighting game experiences I've had in a while).  I think the only negatives that irk me on a regular basis is the wonky interface. Trying to do things like find where to see replays or turning off notifications was confusing at first. It works, but it can be streamlined. One week out connectivity issues are mostly dealth with but stat pages don't seem to work.  Really, as long as you've got the patience to learn and study from your mistakes there's no reason pros and casuals alike can't enjoy this game. The systems and techniques that pros like to use on one another are there, and for the casual player the motion inputs have been simplified and the frame windows widened. And if you're mid-tier it just seems like the best of both worlds.  I understand some are dissapointed in the amount of alternate modes / extras in the game but, in the games defense, we did know exactly what would and would not be in there before the release. If this were SFxT or MVC3 you would be able to point to obviously shady practices but in this case Capom is selling a online-based fighter with extra content to come at a later date and has not presented it as anything more than that. If that's not enough for someone that's ok, but it's up to the consumer to investigate what is and is not present in a potential purchase, so make sure you do that before you consider buying.

(Updated 12.7.2016)  Flowchart Ken's school of tl;dr recommendation:  -Single player is extremely lackluster even by genre's standards. The cinematic story mode is silly, if amusing joke at best, and random nonsense at worst. Rubbish for single player alone.  -Multiplayer and general gameplay works as intended. Definitely recommended.  -Still quite rough around the edges, such as lack of official dinput support and whatnot.  Compared to previous titles and the franchises reputation, Street Fighter V introduces several rather radical changes to movesets and approach to balance as technical layers have been beheaded one by one, favouring good old fundamental babysteps over technical, extravagant and flamboyant balls. Everyone has only one clear set of normal moves as opposed to normals and close normals - the latter only working at essentially point blank range as the name suggests, almost everyone in the cast has an ability dedicated to bypassing or neutralising projectiles outside jumping, many characters' moveset has been drastically changed compared to their previous appearances, heavy attacks can inflict 'crush counter' which opens up even more damaging combo opportunities for mistimed buttons or missing reversals up close, execution barrier has been reduced a lot that even someone who has never played a video game before can in theory dish out decent damage with little training, and the jump from understanding basics to being able to use said basics is far less pronounced than before. It does not mean anyone can learn the game in 10 minutes and level up to sponsored tournament player, simply even that 10 minute training can force even little bit of respect even against competent player by sheer damage output potential from mistakes. It hardly makes up for lack of knowledge or experience in other areas. After all, no amount of simplification can beat experience and good understanding of principles and execution.  Speaking of mechanics, each character has their unique V-Skill, V-Reversal and V-Trigger which uses the new V bar, which is gained by taking damage or using V-Skills. V-Skills range from eliminating damage with the right timing to moves which can bypass projectiles (and doubles as attacks) to 'armoured' moves or extra mobility. V-Reversals use the same V bar and activated by pressing forward during block and three punches (or kicks depending on the character) at the same time. These serve as a way to halt or escape pressure. When V bar is full, V-Trigger is available and its activation varies from countdown timer with new special moves, enhanced special moves, or even single-use special move by itself. To give an example, Ryu's V-Skill improves his projectile speed, damage and stun, adds charge property and at max charge breaks defence. Zangief's V-Skill allows him to essentially suck an opponent closer from afar, allowing him several potential applications to close in the distance and deal some nasty damage. It slightly resembles the FADC combo extender Street Fighter IV functionally without drastically lopsiding use of bar for mere combo extenders to most of the cast, as V bar is always reset inbetween rounds.  Several months in and SFV is pretty well balanced as each character has all the necessary tools to win. The cast has also good focus on quality, each character has their own gameplay vibe and strenghts even if some archetypes overlap. Initial 16 character roster has been expanded to 20, and another 2 are on their way. So far only gameplay aspect veering heavily into on\off territory is its preference for offensive approach and (somewhat) restrictive technical setplay dictated by frame data, as right now it does favour a little bit too much of hitting buttons in random order for victory especially against people who are not as experienced. For those struggling to deal with nonstop pressure, block and V-Reversal is your friend. Looking beyond infancy gimmicks, online specials and bar brawls, match dynamics and causality are pretty clear.  Crossplay deservers wonderful mention too. PC and PS4 users can play together, tossing platform split down the drain. Casual matches have been added alongside ranked matches and searching matches is fairly effortless, if random when it comes to finding an opponent.  But now we get to the fun part everyone has been awaiting and snarking beyond ridicule since the game was released. For every force there is equal but opposite force, for ying must come yang, for every attempt to sound smart on the Internet must come the awful truth nobody really cares.  Above the solid diamondmine of gameplay and mechanics lies huge pile of ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• and landslide's worth of mud to sludge through. Forget quickly fixed launch server issues. For a major release from a major publisher funded by major company, the game is hollow as termites' favourite vacation spot. Capcom Pro Tour explains it a bit but considering how often poor if not even outright broken releases are (rightfully) crucified and burned on whim... eh. SFV was far from broken but simply hollow. I do not care much for single player content in fighting games, but even on the genre's nonexistent SP standards SFV anchored its own foot somewhere in the Atlantic. The (character) story is essentially ~15 minute slugfest against AI as competent as squirrel on drugs trying to fly jet at mach 3, which leaves us survival mode and training with dummy set to AI as only way to play the game without involving human opponent. The cinematic story fares even worse, resembling official fan fiction aiming for Adam West Batman campyness only to climb up a tree posterior-wards. Even the infamous 90s Street Fighter cartoon makes more sense with better entertainment value.  The game forces you play a very quick tutorial once you start it. Not a bad idea but it too much to ask to extend tutoring to training mode? And allow viewing frame data in-game? Under challenges and demonstrations one can find some pointers on par with pro tips to defeat Cyberdemon. Googling information in this day and age is really, really easy, but is proper manual and better guides too much to be asked?  Lobbies have predetermined chat messages which while serve their purpose, is very limited and just plain weird decision since Guilty Gear Xrd came out on PC a while back which allows actual chat in lobbies, matches + supports 4x matches at the same time. Between matches the hangtime worse than on the moon. Imagine someone padded War and Peace on top of War and Peace and maybe Anna Karenina while at it. Character selection feels like someone on the developement team was very fond of screen transitions and animations and stretching out like expanding universe. Capcom Fighters Network does not allow any kind of communication (outside lobbies) either.  There is bizarre irony at work that a game released for both PS4 and PC at the same time lacks direct input support... while PS4 natively supports it. While easy problem to solve with 3rd party software, there are no words. What kind of creative degenerate decided early on in developement to not add dinput? Why not make default keyboard binds as unintuitive as possible and dr‚Äî oh, right. That also happens to be a problem. I'm tempted to guess the person in charge of PC developement had a grudge against raw, basic functions which allows a game to be played in the first place.  As much as the game release went through stereotypical evil overlord game publisher checklist of missing good release station by few counties, multiplayer and gameplay is still 100 carat diamond. With some frustrating caveats and minefields to consider too.
Does what a fighting game is supposed to do, i like it.
It's a good fun game
This game is the best if you are into competitive fighting games. Don't buy it if you are a casual, offline player because the solo content is garbage.

If you care about single player, don't buy this. You'll hate it.  In it's current state, SFV is essentially a multiplayer-only title. Not having functional servers is inexcusable. It's getting better, but the launch situation was pathetic.  Any yet, I'm giving Street Fighter V a postive review. Why? I enjoy the fighting. I love offline competitive play and training mode. For me, the game is a lot of fun.   I realize I'm in the minority. The negative reviews are warranted and Capcom screwed up big time. BUT. This awful launch will pass, content will come, and the fighting will still be excellent. SFV will (eventually) be a game that everyone can enjoy.  EVO. Pro Tour. I get it. But seriously, Capcom. This launch was a disaster.  TL;DR Single player content is a joke, servers are (were?) a mess. When it works, the gameplay is amazing. The balance is fantastic, the game is tournament ready. If you're a competitive player who wants a leg up, buy it. Otherwise ...? Move along, citizen.

This game has got everything you need to start playing, learn the new mechanics and compete; with more unlockables coming down the wire soon.  Capcom are doing right by the SF community. Servers are under strain (as you'd expect for any early provisioning cycle) but I am getting plenty of matches. Sometimes the game won't save stats after a ranked game against ps4 players. This'll probably get fixed soon.  Smooth framerate (even on my 480gtx) no drops.  Controls are not mash-happy, they feel nice, technical and time critical. I'm currently playing with controller not stick, so can't comment on piano-play style.  Reminds me a little bit of the SFIII 3rd in terms of variance control for frame-critical resets.  Oh, and Ryu's 'Mind's Eye' is basically parrying. 8/10

Ask yourself this: 'Are you a hardcore fan of Street Fighter?' By hardcore, I mean you practice combos, perhaps check out the tournament scene and mostly fight your friends and dudes online. If you answered yes, then I recommend this game to you. If you answered no, then I suggest moving on until later in the year when Capcom adds in the more single player oriented stuff and most likely drops the price.  Street Fighter 5 is a  damn  good fighting game at its core. I'm a jaded SF3 vet and while I begrudgingly played SF4, I have to tip my hat to SF5. They really put their heart and soul into this game and it's really a shame that their bare-bones launch did such serious damage to this game's reputation.   But yeah, if you're a hardcore fighting game fan that wants to become the next Diago or Wong, snatch this game up without a second thought. But if you're just a casual dude who wants to play Arcade Mode with a few characters after you get home from work, I'd suggest movin' on and snatchin' up another game.

If you want a fighting game that is easy to get into then this could be it. It teaches you how to play and gives you a challenge on its own and this knowledge can be implemented when you play Online against others.   There will be wins and the will be losses, but with the accumulated experience you will only get better!

Core gameplay is great, but the lag and netcode ruins its online experience. There's nothing more frustrating than successfully landing attack, only to realize a split second later that the game rolls that back and you're the one stuck in the middle of a combo. I mostly just play in the battle lounge with my friends since I know the connection will be okay. It's just disappointing that such a solid game's online experience is plagued by latency issues.

As of release, Street Fighter V has the the fundamental content necessary to be fun for members of the fighting game community looking to plan online or in person.  What it lacks - at the moment - but what is planned to be added in future patches, is the single player content. The story mode is really just a series of prologues, there are no trials or other singleplayer features one may have expected based on previous Street Fighter games.  What does this mean?  If you care about getting online and fighting, training and discovering combos in training mode, and working to build the foundation of the community. Grab it now and play your heart out.  If you're looking for more single player content and data, more feature rich online multiplayer and other offerings that, for example, Ultra Street Fighter IV, offered, then keep your eye on this title for a future buy.  A lot of fighting games start out with a small roster and content base, and then over the many years of its life, it grows, expands, and refines.
Don't listen to the hate bandwagon. Game is fantastic. Netcode is great and gameplay is better than ever. Who gives a ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• about arcade mode?

So it's been a long while since the game came out and after many patches and updates (some not great, others essential) the game is pretty much how it's gonna be barring balance updates / character updates.  The mechanics are brilliant, the netcode is much improved over USF4 (if I search RANKED with 3+ bars only, it's as if I'm playing with people in my living room), the RANKED queue search time could be better but it's rare that you wait longer than 2-3 mins for a match and it's full compatible with my 360 pad for Windows and my Q4RAF fightstick.   The button config is also much improved and is the easiest iteration so far in terms of being able to remap buttons on your gamepad / stick. Have to fiddle with the modes on the fightstick a little to get it to register but I think that's down to Windows only recognising it in a certain mode rather than the game.  Overall, if you like fighting games with simple to learn but hard to master mechanics and online play, I would recommend the game to you.  If you want to play Arcade mode and have a good storydriven fighting game experience (in the vein of Mortal Kombat XL which has just been updated for PC or the old skool Soul Caliber games) then look elsewhere because the storymode on offer here is threadbare and comes across as if it was written by a team of 5 year olds who just watched Dragonball Z for the first time.   8/10

Overall this is an amazing game.  But first and foremost at its current state, this is a game for the fighting game community, Im coming from the competitive smash scene myself. Once this game was announced and saw gameplay I knew I had to try out this series. Having very little street fighter experience and jumping right in was daunting but it has been a rewarding journey throughout.  The animations for each individual character are very detailed and a joy to look at. I found myself picking random characters to look at their idle animations because it was that good. the visuals really contribute to the stages and their backgrounds (Hillside Plaza is beast!)  Training mode is robust and much can be learned from going to the lab and practicing a few combos. Practice various scenarios, mix-ups etc.   The original soundtrack for this game is also epic and I get hyped listening to the stage/character select music.  Characters currently available and to come all look unique and amazing to play. The introduction of the V trigger system really makes for fun play, making comebacks possible.  If you enjoy the aspect of testing your metal online against more and more challenging people online this is the game for you. Winning a close match is one of the most rewarding parts of this game, it's not easy but through a robust training mode you can level up and face all the world warriors.

Pros: Learning the game is fairly easy, mastering it will take plenty of time, fun mechanics, graphics are nice, Chun-li's Battle Outfit (y), has potential to be an even greater game, casuals can pick up the game and have fun without feeling the frustration of not being able to do combos like in SF4  Cons: (My opinions) Rollback is the worst, Ps4 to PC fights always seem to bring lag to the table even if it says 5 bars, the ragequits are very potent, lacking in the single player content, NO arcade mode (weird), getting colors in this game is very boring with survival mode being the most grindy feeling thing ever since the AI randomly goes from braindead to input reading monsters  Most of these cons will be worked out in the future, i'm confident of it, so I will continue to play

Fighting games are about mechanics mastery. Street Fighter has always been about mastering the fight system of each iteration and using your mastery to compete with other humans. The reason that people buy fighting games is the same reason people play MOBAs, to 'git gud' at them and become able to beat other players. I bought Street Fighter V for this reason.   Many are concerned about the lack of singleplayer modes. I can sympathize with this, but I must mention that if your goal is to gain mastery of the fight system in order to beat better and better players, your time is better spent fighting other humans rather than AIs. As it stands, if your goal is mechanics mastery, the game has what you need it to have in it right now. If you're choosing not to buy this game because it lacks singleplayer content, you probably weren't going to play it for more than a month. I presume that those who are declining purchasing the game because it lacks singleplayer content are those who already don't see the value, don't see the depth in what the game already has to offer in its multiplayer mode. If you don't see the value in that, then I assume you want to play Street Fighter V because it's the Next Big Game coming out. It's something to occupy your time for a short while before the Next Big Game after it comes out. This is a mistake. Fighting games, like MOBAs, are not about occupying you for a short amount of time. If you want to get any meaning out of this game, it is not such a game that you play for two hours after work before you go to sleep for the next day, forgetting about it once Dark Souls 3 comes out. It is a game that you must not forget about if you wish to gain the fullest amount of value from it. It is a game that will take many hundreds of hours to gain a respectable level of skill for. It is a game that requires a time commitment that is daunting compared to many other video game genres. If you do not have the patience to put the time in to get good, I do not think this game will be worth 60 dollars to you. And assuming you are waiting on the game already until it has its singleplayer modes patched in, you will get about 8 hours or so of playtime out of that. Then you might try online and get absolutely wrecked. You might spend two or so weeks trying to get good at online play, and then you'll quit because you're unwilling to put in the amount of time you will realize is necessary to beat these players. This is not meant to be a put down, or to be dismissive. This is just the experience of a vast majority of people when they first play fighting games. It was my experience. It will likely be yours as well. Most Steam users are at least familiar with DoTA, so I'll use it as a similar case. Street Fighter is a game that asks even more time of the player than DoTA does in order to get the most out of it. Please consider this fact before you make your purchase.  In summary: This game is not for you if you're not interested in player versus player and are unwilling to put in the time required to harden muscle memory/gain general knowledge of the fighting system. I am, so that's why I'm recommending this game. This game is likely not for you if you only want to play singleplayer modes. I may be wrong on this point. You may find 60 dollars of enjoyment in the singleplayer modes the game will patch in within a few months that will likely only last 6-8 hours. If you feel that's the case, of course spend 60 dollars on the game, but if you find yourself wanting, don't say I didn't tell you so. ;)

I wanted to hold off on reviewing Street Fighter V until more content was released, since Capcom themselves admitted that the game was incomplete at launch. Nonetheless, I immediately bought the game as soon as it came out because I wanted to jump straight into the online multiplayer mode. Since then, I have been regularly playing it every now and then, and it still hasn't gotten old yet to this day. Furthermore, there are still plans to release additional content in the future. Now that the story mode has been released, I feel like I can give the game a fair review at this point.  The biggest attraction of Street Fighter V remains the online multiplayer mode. The battle system has more depth to it than any previous iteration of Street Fighter, and there are plenty of opportunities to make a comeback against an opponent who is overwhelming you. Your character's V-gauge will fill up as you take damage, allowing you to perform special techniques that could potentially reverse the direction the match is heading in. At the same time, your character's special gauge will also be filling up both as you give and receive damage, so it is still rewarding to go on the offensive. The developers also did a great job at ensuring that the characters in this game are all balanced (well, maybe except for Zangief), and that the play style for each character is a unique challenge to tackle and become accustomed to. Personally, I was satisfied by this game's multiplayer mode alone, but I understand that this might not be the case for everyone else.  Thankfully, Capcom has added enough single player content to keep many players satisfied by this point. Sure, they still haven't added Arcade Mode yet, but the amount of single-player content currently available was enough to satiate my needs of fighting against the game's AIs. This is just my personal taste, but I found that I didn't need Arcade Mode considering everything else the game had to offer. Survival Mode helped test any foolproof strageties I'd thought up against hordes of AI opponents, and Challenge Mode helped me practice vital combos to the characters I wanted to become familiar with. The long-anticipated Story Mode was well worth the wait (in my opinion) and definitely has the most fully fleshed-out plot in any Street Fighter game to date. It also pays homage to many of the earlier Street Fighter games in ways that might surprise some people.  The only real complaint I have about this game is that there still aren't too many characters on the roster just yet, although I am aware that this will change in future updates. Plus, the amount of variance between the playstyles of the different characters is enough to keep me entertained for now. Despite a difficult launch, I still have very high hopes for Street Fighter V, and I believe the amount of depth the game possesses is enough to keep most hardcore players hooked - therefore, I would certainly recommend it to fans of the series.

In it's current state this game is orientated towards the more competetive types of people, If you're not competetive then steer clear of this one.   -No Arcade mode. -Story mode is so easy, short, and sloppy, even a baby beat it no problem.  -Additional colors are stowed away behind a tedious and challenging 'Survival mode' -Game is still unfinished  -The anti rage quitter 'system' that will be put into the game is a joke.   This game isn't perfect AT ALL, objects clip through characters, the lip syncing is trash (although it does seem like a capcom staple to do this crap now), It takes forever to be matched with someone as opposed to other fighting games, some characters look awful and the English voice actors have lines that are delivered so cringy (devour-hour!).   Despite all of that I can honestly say that I love the game because I am competetive and I love to work hard towards becoming great in a game and move up in rank constantly.

The best fighting game if you are new to the genre. No 2 minutes long combos during which you can go make a cup of tea while your opponent juggles you in the air like a rag doll. Game of street fighter V looks more like a hand-paper-scissors on steorids. Easy to get into, hard to master.

This game os awesome, and the gameplay is really focused on multiplayer. I don't really care about arcade mode (never played in MKX for example). But I guess some people really do care, so that's a no-no, but the game is well balanced, connections are good, netcode is good, gameplay is very polished and very diverse. Capcom needs to re-think their DLC prices and policy, it's overpriced. But they said this is going to be a game to be supported during many years, so I guess we'll get arcade mode eventually, and more ways to earn fight money.  Pros: Visuals Gameplay Multiplayer Easier combos Diverse roster Netcode Polished  Cons: Lack of single player content Fight money is limited, we need something extra to earn, daily challenges maybe?

It is not perfect, but I'm loving it. They did release it before it was 100% and could have avoided the backlash if they put more emphasis on that fact that they released it for the tournament.
