So, it's time I updated my review to 'recommended' With this latest update, this is the game that they should have released from the start.   Gameplay 10/10  Much in the same way that other studios fail to duplicate the polish of Nontendo's Mario platformers. Same can be said for 'fighter' studios trying to duplicate SF's polish. The gameplay is super smooth and really handles perfectly. There is no other fighter on the market that outshines SF in this category and it is the most important category.  Graphics 10/10 This boils down to taste. I love the way this game looks. Unreal Engine delivers cartoon style graphics with outstanding color, shadows and aniumations. Top shelf work.  Bugs 6/10 Although a lot of the bugs have been fixed, the amount of problems players have been having is unacceptable for an expensive AAA title. They should have called their release 'Early Access' because that was the level of polish. It plays much better now but there is still a chance that new players will run into problems on PC.  Roster 7/10 What is there is awesome.. it's just there's not much there. This will change as Capcom slowly releases content (stages, alt stages, characters, costumes, etc.) it's all slowly dropping.  Pay Model 5/10 The game costs $60 and you don't get much for that. Each additional character costs $6 a pop along with new stages, costumes and all costing a few bucks. You can buy almost everything with FM (fight money) but Capcom makes sure you have to grind your tailbone off to get it. Plus, all the costumes you really want are not available to purchase with FM. Real $ only for those.  Story Mode 7/10 I read a lot of bad things about story mode. When I played it it wasn't as bad as I was lead to believe. Injustice had the best story mode. MKX was like playing through a really bad B movie with cool fight scenes, and it was fun in that way. SFV story mode is like a corny, silly, comic book come to life. It's at its best when it is being stupid funny. It's at its worst when it's trying to be taken serious. I enjoy sitting through the story. The thing that really hurts story mode is this. No difficulty selection. You have to play the first run through on easy, so you can close your eyes and button mash to the end. Second playthrough is on hard which feels more appropriate. You can earn double the FM for beating both modes so that's nice but there should be an option for difficulty from the beggining.  Online 8/10 I'm not an expert in online mode yet. Haven't put in a ton of hours. Still, I have always found matches easily, relatively lag free play, not many rage quitters left and cross play has worked great. If there were some sort of VOIP I'd give this an even higher score. If I run into more issues online I'll adjust the score later.  Overall 8/10 I know the scores average out to 7.5/10 but the roster score will go up as the list expands and the bug squashing has been better as of late so I'll round up. If you have been on the fence, now is a good time to jump in!
Sure that game is a little bare bones in regards to overall content but the online experience has been so much fun I just have to recommend it!

If you love the depth and mastery of fighting and you like video games , this is 10/10.... If you're not competitive and only want to chill while fighting things offline, this is 2/10. So...are you a real fighter???? All other fighting games are videogames. SFV is about the players....this is crafted to feel like a real fight between 2 minds instead of a technical contest. It's an infinite learning process but once you get good and fight an equal lvl opponent (the only way to enjoy the game), you will feel why sfv is special.    11/10 for me.

While not perfect and at the moment lacking content, it is worth more than Mortal Kombat X will ever be worth. Why? My worst online fight performance wise ran better than my best mkx one. No joke. Pros:  + Great graphiqs, colorful and beautiful art. + Great music. + Great performance and game is well optimised ( Unless you play on a piece of **** ). + Cross platform with ps4. + Online performance is awesome ( Despite launch server problems ). + My sf4 fightpad works with no problems. + Nice system to follow players, view replays, add friends etc. + Years of promised support for the game.  Negatives. - Lack of options at launch, like, no arcade modes challenge modes etc, meaning if you want to play solo you literaly have zero good modes. - Story mode available at launch is a total joke. - Survival mode is the worst mode ever in fighting games, and this one hides colors for costume behind stupid requirements. - Game decided to minimize charge characters ( for whatever reason Vega is no longer a charge character, **** you Capcom ) - Micro transaction scheme that could go both ways once more modes are released in march, stay tuned.   All in all, i keep the game and have no regrets, i recomend it. It is really our only awesome fighting game. Don't trust the negative steam reviews. ( though the complaints about current lack of single player modes are justified. If you must have them and don't care about online, hold on until they get released as your only current use for the game will be to get massacred online )

First day I had no problem getting on the servers then today (Which is 2/17/2016) I logged in, got on the server, did a little training mode, got booted from the server, spent 5 minutes getting back on, got on again, then promptly got booted.   Gameplay-wise its up there with the best of the franchise. Each character is unique and has their own feel to them. Series staples like Ken, Ryu, and Chun-Li feel new because of the V-Trigger system. I sum SFV up in one sentence. -There may not be a lot there but what is there is amazing.  That being said it follows the history of Capcom Street Fighter releases so here is a short summary of what you are going to get.  The Good  - The Fighting: No seriously this is easily one of the best Street fighters released. The actual fighting is fast and fun and extremely well-polished. If you are a fan of the SF series you will feel right at home and if you‚Äôre new it one of the easiest and cleanest Street Fighters to start with.   -The Characters: Every character is unique, interesting and pretty well balanced. They have a great and unique cast this time around bringing a lot of veterans back, some fresh faces, and some fun surprises. The small cast is also great for learning match ups, and experimenting with playstyles, and learning the game.   -How it Runs: 60FPS, 0 Sound glitches, Beautiful graphics. This one is simple, it runs and it runs damn well. Can't ask for much more there.  -Training Mode: In short, it‚Äôs what you've always wanted in training mode. Lab time has never been more rewarding.   The Bad  - There isn't much there: This is many peoples biggest complaint right now for good reason. 12 characters, 4 Modes, and a lack of costumes and colors is all you are really getting with your money. Treat it like early access, 60 bucks for more stuff down the road. Story mode is short, a few easy fights and some voice acted cutscenes. No Alts or colors for really anyone. It really is bare bones.   - Controller Support: There is no native controller or fightistick support. You cannot customize your controller settings either. That being said there are 3rd party apps that are very easily to download and use in order to connect with your fightstick. After using one I can now launch the game and have no problems using my stick.   The Ugly  -Server Issues: Servers are unstable at the time of writing this. Online matches are hard to connect to and can be very laggy and unusable. On top of that fight money to unlock the characters coming in the coming months are un-earnable right now due to the online connection problems. Hopefully this will get fixed soon.  In Summary  Regardless of its problems this is easily one of the best technical fighting games and one of the best Street Fighters Capcom has released. From the pure fighting aspect this game will not disappoint you. Its launch has been sketchy but hey it‚Äôs better that vanilla SF4.

This might be the best Street Fighter entry.  The gameplay is increadibly tight. Each character is well balanced and only a few match-ups are strongly oneside (Zangief vs Dhalsim) which is a hallmark of a great fighting game. The new v mechanics are well designed and help make each character feel truly unique. The execution skills required are very friendly to new comers compared to past entries.  The netcode is mostly fantastic with a few occasional issues with rollback. Match making during the early stages of a game always lead to occasional skill mismatches but from what I can see that shouldn't be the case once more of the good players continue to ascend the ranks and the many different leagues become more evenly populated.  The character background stories are fine, nothing special. Short, easy matches to help give you the background of the character you're interested in and unlock a story oriented costume (you'll still have to buy this costume in the store, once the store is open). Survival is beatable, there were issues early in the release because of the server issues which have been largely eliminated. Survival could be alot better, the need to use each costume for each character to unlock all possible color options is frustrating. Survival also has entirely too many matches of disparate skill levels.  With free updates coming (new characters, new story and challenge modes) I can't help but be excited. If you're new to fighting games and have a desire to play multiplayer (not playing multiplayer is like playing a CoD game just for the story, the multiplayer is the real meat of the game) I strongly recommend this game.

Street Fighter V, even as it sits, is a very tight, wonderfully accessible game that caters to both old and new fans alike. Though there are quite a few missing or not-fully-fleshed-out features, such as Challenge mode, the Shop, etc., this is because the fans of the beta and what not begged capcom to release it early, which they did. Not to mention, these features are not absent completely, but are merely coming as an update in March. The game will also have a great many roster updates as well, with 6 characters being added in just the first update. The online functionality has it's flaws, but I've not encountered anything that warrants a negative review of this title. The worst it gets is taking a long time to find an online opponent, but even this is circumvented by a feature that allows you to search for online fights as a background process while you do other things or play other modes like Survival or the Story previews. Update 2/18  Updating this review now that many server issues have been addressed.   Pros:   Looks Great: No frame rate issue from my computer. Game looks nice  Plays Well: If you played USF4 then you kinda know what your getting into. Game on the surface feels similar but the more you play the more the difference come out.   Lots of promise: Capcom is looking to support this game long term and there are 6 characters promised. No matter how you feel about the pay/grind gate, this game looks like its going to have a lot of characters and be supported for a while, and hey, that costs money guys.  The game shows hope now but still needs time. Its a fun play but...  Cons:   Long loading time for online play: Once you find an oppenent the game will essentailly freeze for about 20 -30 seconds sometimes a bit longer before launching you into online match.   Matching can(rarely for me) be a bit laggy: Honestly not a huge problem for me but occasionally you will come against someone who seems to have bad internet and they'll lag. Seems better then SF4 though.  Online Lobbys 2 Man until March: Probably for server stability or otherwise haven't built out all the features yet but online lobbies are limited to 2 people. There is not spectator option. Only really a problem if you have a bunch of friends you want to play with.  Limited Single Player Options: The story is not yet fully completed will take about 2 hours to complete all the missions for all 16 characters. After that your left with survival and training. Survival is just match after match and is used to unlock bonus colors, and training is training.   Over all I think the game shows some promise. Given a few months the game will be filled out and it most if not all my complaints will be address. I'll try and remember to update this review in march.

While it's true that Street Fighter 5 is a little bare bones in terms of game modes at launch, the actual meat of a competitive fighting game is all here. Compared to SF4, the online is on another level in terms of quality, cross-platform matches can play as smooth as PC to PC matches, and I've only had a handful of laggy matches in general. On top of this, all the things SF5 is lacking, like a cinematic story mode, 3+ person fight lobbies, etc are coming for free in the coming months.  Right now, Street Fighter 5 is a fine cut of meat, only it's a little dry. We'll get the gravy periodically starting next month.

This game gives me mixed feelings. As far as the quality of the gameplay, graphics, and time put into this game its great. The fighting is the best its ever been. Its smooth, easy to get into, and exciting. Where this game flops is in its lack of content. There are only 16 characters available to start. Now this would be forgivable if there wasnt so much else missing from this game. There are only a handful of stages, theres no AI versus mode. The only way to battle AI is in the training mode. In order to play versus mode you MUST have a second controller. 1P controller, and 2P keyboard isnt even an option. Theres no cinematic storymode. It will be added for no extra charge later however, but thats not until June. The shop hasnt opened in game either. There is also no arcade mode. As far as online goes there is supposed to be 8 player lobbies, but they are not available yet. Extra costumes still have yet to be available as well. Of course the larger lobbies, extra costumes, and shop will all be opened sometime in March. The end decision is I do in fact recommend this game, but wait until more of the content and features are available. Give it until at least the end of March before you pick this up, and maybe even June.

If you actually like playing fighting games competitively, Street Fighter 5 has fixed a huge number of the issues with 4's gameplay. The V skill and V trigger systems enforce a level of uniquity for each character in a similar way to the Drive mechanic in Blazblue. Unintended mechanics that became overwhelmingly prolific in SF4 such as crouch tech are removed, and the game has a hard priority system which tie breaks when moves would normally trade in SF4, encouraging the use of normals other than lights. Light normals also confirm into less. There is a 3 frame buffer that makes impractical links a thing of the past, and the crush counter system ensures you are aptly rewarded for respecting your opponent's DP or going for the risky counter hit. The new characters are all interesting and fun to play (extra special shoutouts to Fang, a character with an extremely unique keepaway playstyle revolving around poison that clears if you successfully attack him, and Rashid, who breaks a number of the series' established rules, having multiple ways to change trajectory in the air and a dash with no fixed distance from which he can attack), and the game is graphically a lot more pleasing than 4, if still a little behind most AAA games. Don't let poor steam reviews decieve you, it's captivated the genre's fans, and has already broken the record for most sign ups at the biggest fighting game tournament of all, Evo. Rollback netcode has done wonders for the game, and while those on poor connections might have a bad experience in neutral, lag will no longer fear with your combos or wakeup game (unless you're connected to the internet by carrier pigeon).  However, if you find competitive fighting games difficult to penetrate or don't want to put down the large amount of time required to learn them, there's little for you here. That's not me trying to be insulting, there's factually no worthwhile learning tools for concepts beyond basic controls, or anything to appeal to audiences that aren't experienced with the genre. Lacking proper single player options or even a decent tutorial (with the promise that these are coming later), this game was clearly rushed out for the existing fighting game community to be ready for the Capcom tournament season. Story mode is a rushed demo of the full story which won't be in the game until June, and survival mode is an uninteresting grind.  Recommended for stellar multiplayer experience (in terms of both gameplay and online infrastructure) and a fresh and inspired take on a beloved franchise, but if that alone isn't worth ¬£45 to you, you should skip.

While this new installment of Street Fighter did not come with all the standard content that the previous games did on release day, the core gameplay itself is very solid. However, at the time of writing this, they have added quite a bit of content and continue to do so. There is a fully fledged story mode which takes a 1~2 hours to complete (provided you don't skip any cutscenes). They've added challenges/missions to help players to gain in-game currency a little faster. There are 6 more characters added to the original roster and will continue to add more over time. There new stages and also added the promised stage transitions for each stage. I don't believe there are currently any balance changes at the moment as they seem to be focused on adding content, but I'm sure they will shift that focus to balance changes once they feel there is substantial content.  I have mixed feelings about how the game handles network play. Unlike the USF4, it uses roll back. While roll back does not greatly interrupt the input of your commands/combos, the downside is that you may see some 'teleporting' if you do not have a very good connection with your opponent. If you do have a good connection with your opponent, then for the most part, it's very playable with either little to no 'lag/teleporting'. Technology has come a long way and has allowed games that emphasize lag-free play to play with others around the world. While it's not currently perfect, I think it's a great achievement thus far and eventually will improve over time as we discover better ways to code the networking. Don't expect to be lag-free if you're playing against someone from the other side of the world. We're just not there yet.  I only recommend this game if you are a fan of fighting games as it really does not appeal to casuals. In most cases, casuals are probably looking to play the story mode/AI and play with their friends only. That's not to say that they shouldn't purchase the game, but they probably won't appreciate/enjoy the game as much as hardcore fighting game fans would. If you like competitive gaming and want a challenge, this is probably for you as this has a high skill cap and a steep learning curve.

I still recommend waiting for a sale though.

The legend says, that in a distant past, producer and gamers respected each other. Producers delivered good finished polished games. And gamers happily supported them. But life aint fairy tale baby. Those who respond 'yeah but capcom told the people that the game won't be complete at launch' are full of sh*t. The game is now slightly more playable for optimus based PC like mine. Althought it's finally using the correct graphic card, the game still has some random fps drop now and then. And the more you play the more those fps drops stack up. To the point where it goes back to 50 fps after 10 / 20 fights, loading a new map seems to help but not that much. Only solution is to restart the game.

Pros:   Even though it is bare-bones right now, the fighting is a ton of fun. If you like to play people online like I do, I think you will have a good time.   Combos are easier than in SF4 and it works out nicely because you are able to get into the mind games of one on one fights much quicker without that technique barrier holding you back. The gameplay feels great. Everything about the ACTUAL game seems to be great.  The features that are missing will be added someday.  Cons:  The features will be added someday, meaning they are not here now.  The game feels unfinished already and with survival mode being the only viable 1 player option right now, it's even worse because survival mode sucks.  If they fix the complete waste of time that is survival mode I would reccomend this game. It being hard is not my complaint. It is that it wastes your time.   Example: In normal survival mode, fights 1-25 are easy, but you hit 25-30 and the difficulty ramps up hugely. So fights 1-25 just feel like a waste of time. If you lose on fight 29, you have to start all over again because its survival. Seriously, balance out the difficulty. I shouldn't be able to win fights 1-25 with crouching heavy kick. Then lose in some fight between 25-30 because the computer suddenly blocks, counters, punishes, and combos. It is the most jarring and frustrating part of survival mode.   Not to mention the fact that you have to be connected to the server while playing it or it doesn't count. Imagine getting to level 48 in hard survival mode, and disconnecting from the server. That is a lot of time wasted.

The core game is good (this is Street Fighter after all), however this release is so barebones (and the few modes featured in the game so poorly implemented) that I would not recommend purchasing it for at least a few months until Capcom has hopefully gotten their ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• together and fixed everything.  One of the features in the launch version of the game is an extremely short story mode with costumes that you 'unlock' but can only use in story mode until a future update, at which point you will have to purchase them using in game currency. There's also a survival mode where you battle computer controlled opponents for a set number of matches in order to unlock colors for the character you complete the mode with. This is a poor substitute for arcade mode as it takes muuuuuuuuuch longer to get through. This is the first fighting game that has required grinding.  The online was barely functional at launch, and, though a little better now, is still horribly implemented. For example, there is no punishment for ragequitting. There was a sweet spot of about a week between when they fixed the unplayable launch servers and when people started realizing it was punishment free to disconnect. As of now I get rage disconnects on about 30-50% of matches I am about to win.  There is a Battle Lounge which you can use to invite friends or other players to battle. This would be where I spent the majority of my time if it weren't for the fact that the netcode in this game is horrible so my friends and I all experience constant rollback and framedrops when playing with eachother. NOTE: I am reviewing this game after the release of the September update. I didn't buy this game during it's release, because I heard a lot of criticisms of this game including: lacking contents, no Arcade Mode, and awful online multiplayer. I bought this game in the summer sales on Steam at June 2016. Anyway, on to the review.  The Good: + Street Fighter 5's roster is not large but quite fantastic it has some playable characters that didn't make it in Street Fighter 4 including: Karin, R.Mika, Alex, and Urien returning in this game as playable characters. + This game's gameplay is great with simple mechanics, easy combos, and it's not hard to pick up for beginner. The V-Trigger is awesome; it grants a character's powerups, unique abilities, etc. for a period of time. + The General Story Mode called, 'A Shadow Falls' is not a bad story mode; it's passable. The cutscenes' animation is used from this game's graphics instead of SF4's terrible anime animation; they look good. This is story mode is a FREE DLC.  The Bad: - The Arcade Mode (the most common mode in any fighting games) is still not in this game as of today. - The Character Story Mode sucks; It's where you play through every playable character's story. They're very short with rushed writing and a few matches to win in order advance the story and the art looks either decent or bad.  The Worst: ~ Juri's SF5 theme is one of the WORST soundtracks I have ever heard in any video games period. It's absolutely garbage compared to her SSF4 theme. ~ On the September update, Capcom released a malware on the PC version called, 'rootkit' (or Capcom.sys). This was Capcom's biggest screw up.  Randomness: This game's online multiplayer is just random; some matches can run good but some can run bad. Even if you battle against your opponent online who has a good 5-Bar signal, the chances are it could run bad. If it runs bad you may run into some slow-downs, skipped frames, and sometimes brief game freeze. I wish Capcom will add the GGPO netcode for this game so that it will make online matches playable. Mortal Kombat XL has GGPO and I heard that it runs very good. Oh, this game also has cross-play feature allowing PC and PS4 owners battle each other online. Nice feature.  Comment(s): I want to criticize this game for not featuring Direct Input and the game has messed up keyboard settings. But fortunately, I downloaded and installed a software called, 'TocaEdit X360 Controller Emulator' that allows Direct Input for any PC games; especially Street Fighter 5. It works great with my old PS3 arcade stick. After you downloaded and installed this game, please get this software immediately. 'Vs. CPU' is finally added in the 'Versus Mode' allowing you to battle against a CPU opponent with selectable difficulty. Thank God.  Verdict: I like Street Fighter 5; it has nice roster and great gameplay. However, I can only recommend Street Fighter 5 for those who play fighting games competitively. So, this game is not for everybody. I'm leaving this review as, 'Not Recommended' for now, since this is Season 1. When Season 2 is released, I don't mind going back to re-review this game again.  Thanks for reading!

Update: I've recently doubled my amount of playtime following a number of updates for the game and the resolution of the Rootkit debacle that put the games in the spotlight for very much the wrong reason.  While Capcom managed to add a large amount of Paid DLC and a security threat - it's unfortunate to say that the game is still plagued by many of the same issues apparent during it's launch. There is still no support for customizing your bindings using a keyboard.  The game breaking stability problem during Online matches is still there. Many matches are unenjoyable due to the models glitching around constantly. The connection filter seem utterly sporadic. Even when set to '5 only' - I still found myself being paired with people on other continents. This raises a few eyebrows since I tested queueing for a ranked match alongside a local friend and the game failed to pair us despite a relatively close LP rating.  They do get some bonus points for actually providing free content like Story Mode, and maybe even Arcade Mode one day.  The vertict still stands: It's a Street Fighter with fewer mechanics and a smaller roster than its predecessor, though it will grow over time. They made it easier for beginners to perform combos due to the removal of 1-frame links. You have to rely on Third-party software to customize bindings if you use a keyboard which isn't that much of a hassle - but it shouldn't be necessary for a AAA-title.  The biggest flaw is the online play. Currently PC players are facing a major issue reportedly caused by either player minimzing out of the game which inflicts a desync that results in models teleporting all over the place. There are also a lot of server downtime, and disconnects are not uncommon.  There's still a lot of content missing, which is scheduled to be released at a later time, but it keeps on being delayed.  It's absolutely not worth its current price unless you're a huge Street Fighter fan.

I dont even know where to start. Lets just skip broken launch and bare bones content and lets get straight to mechanics of game. I understand, Capcom tried to bring normal (casuals) players to street fighter universe but what they displayed in street fighter 5 is absolutely unjustifiable.   There is no challenging mode or trial, that would teach you basics and advanced stuff. If you want to learn another character you need to stick to ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• menu and training mode. Amazingly enough, this still feels like half a game. I bought this during the hype of EVO 2016 when it was conveniently discounted to $40. While this may seem like a bargain, I didn't realize that at least 4 characters and fight stage arenas are hidden behind a paywall. I don't want to buy this game at a discount just to end up spending more money trying to get the rest of the content. I feel like Capcom should have done more to make things right with regular consumers like myself. I understand that the focus of this game was at 'tournament' players from the onset - but Capcom never advertised it that way. Almost a 1/2 year later, and I still feel like it makes more sense to just save your money and watch this on Twitch.   For those of you who don't care about spending money, the game actually feels pretty damn good on PC despite the limited content. I was able to pick up and use my Elite controller without issue and I even won a few matches before requesting the refund. The netcode is pretty good - I didn't notice continous problems like I thought I would. The cross play between PS4 and PC players is interesting and ensures you will be able to find a match online (or at least while EVO is being broadcast). Turning this up to 1440p resolution is an absolute visual treat - the artwork in this game definitely deserves praise.   In conclusion, buy this game if you are a fan of the series and want to kick someone's ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• online after a long day of working in your cubicle for less money than you are worth. However, understand that Capcom is not doing you a favor - you still have to pay extra for all the characters and Lord only knows where you can download extra character costumes. With enough points, you can also earn characters through playing the game for free; however, realistically that ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• takes forever. If someone did manage to earn enough points to buy the DLC characters for free, please let the world know how you exercised that amount of patience!

I remember when I was just a little Chowd, and I would love playing Street Fighter arcade machines whenever/wherever I could find one. There really weren't any combos, or v-triggers, or ultimate moves- but the game was fun. It had a soul that was undeniably evident, and it oozed with the love that Capcom clearly put into making it- this explains why I would constantly have to wash my hands after handling slimy joysticks and buttons... probably had nothing to do with pizza grease. Anyways, I purchased Street Fighter 5 because of my love for the originals. Sadly, however, the game has become a money-making shell of it's former self. I don't know how one of my favorite childhood games has been twisted into such a steaming pile of perverted, shameless, hollow, forced, half-baked, sewage boy excrement. Unfortunately, I forced myself to play it for longer than 2 hours, so I could not get a refund for the worst-spent $60 of my life... besides for that one time I bought Charles Barkley's Shut Up and Jam. Only difference is- I wrote them a letter when I was around 10 years old and they actually gave me a refund.  Chowd- out.

I can describe Street Fighter V with one word: laziness.  I been playing Street Fighter 2,3 and 4 quite a lot. Especially 4 was a long time favorite for about 5 years, and i had great experiences with that brilliant game. Unlike Street Fighter V, it was a complete game for me.   Crapcom wanted to bring 'THE' Fighting Game, which was considered to be a long timer like Street Fighter IV was.  By its current state, I think that even a game like Shaq Fu would do better.  Lets start off by mentioning the 'Story' mode.  The story mode is one of the perfect examples of crampcom being lazy as ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•.  There are 3 enemys for each character, and some pictures related to their story. I mean Capcom, I know you focused on the Game itself and not on the Story, but atleast show that you tried.  For anyone who enjoyed playing Arcade in SFIV, you wont be enjoying this.  The worst of the game is the 'Survival' mode. I mean, this mode is just pure cancer. You have to put a ton of time into playing against the AI opponent you can crush easily, and get colours for each character that depend on the difficulty you play. If you want to know more about this crazy fun mode read some other reviews, I am not in the mood to describe this mode. Its just a punch to the face to any Street Fighter Fan.   Instead of allowing the Ranked Match Lobbys like in SFIV, you now have to configure your 'Battle Settings' with your favorite Character, Stage and so on. I mean Capcom wtf. Who of you guys came up with this great idea of leaving the Lobbys behind us and replace them for this ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• system?   Gotta say i had no laggs though. BUT about 5 times of playing 15 games, the Server wont send any results of my matches and I didnt get any points whatsoever..   Lets go on with the bad things, for me personally I think the combos are way to flat and boring. Comparing it to the Combo System in SFIV is a joke, I mean i understand that it was made to get new players to play the game better but seriously, I feel like every character has like 2-3 Combos. The V-Trigger combos  aren't interesting for me at all. You arent even able to link a cr. lp to a cr. mp, which has been completely normal in SFIV but in SFV you can't. I dont see the logic here. FADC Combos in SFIV really showed off your skill, and made the Game quite interesting. That is not the case here.  All in all, dont buy this game at its current state thank you crampcom for messing up a long awaited game everyone was absolutely hyped about.

This is the third time I'm editing this. I'll delete this review if I have to do it again.  I wrote a review for this game a couple months back not recommending it. Now that I've approached it in a different way, I can recommend it but only to a specific group of people.  ONLY get this game if you can get it cheap (physical copies go for ¬£20-¬£30, I managed to get it for ¬£25) and/or only get it if your style of play is solely multiplayer. If you got this for single player, you will be extremely disappointed.  I like fighting games but I'm usually pretty bad at them and never try to learn them... ever so I don't tend to go online and always stick to local or single player. Street Fighter V changed that in a way for me as I just wanted to get the most out of the game and the fact that I can't afford the season pass for characters so I depend solely on fight money. Online is fun and it honestly has gotten better. I still get the awful match now and again but that's more down to the connection between both players. The netcode has improved since my last review and I am getting games a lot faster. If you're still getting bad games, you could always use the lobby system. You don't get fight money but you're assured of a good connection. The matchmaking, however, is garbage. I played today at Bronze rank and fought super bronze which is okay but I did so terribly, I went down to Rookie and I still was getting Super Bronze, some with triple my LP. This seriously needs to be fixed. I also wish there was a character select screen for ranked and casual rather than changing your 'favourite character' on your profile every time you wanna play someone different but I guess it isn't an issue if you don't have any secondaries.  Other than that, the graphics are fine, the mechanics are solid (Balance is sort of an issue. Expect to see a thousand Nashes and Karins online) and Capcom are listening to their fans... slowly but surely. There's still barely anything regarding single player content (the main story mode they brought out a month or so ago can be beaten in about 3 hours and has a dreadful story) but again, only buy this if it's on the cheap or if you think you will really get into the meta game... or you know, you could buy Street Fighter IV.  TLDR; Only buy if you wanna get into competitive.

Unless you play on playing offline a lot, don't even bother.  I'm just going to focus on the online because otherwise listing all the ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• wrong with this game would take too long.   This game's online is a complete disaster. The matchmaking takes 5-10 minutes to find an opponent, and when you're starting out you can expect them to be several leagues higher than you. The skill of your opponent typically doesn't matter, because even if you filter matchmaking to only accept 5 bar connections, they will usually end up lagging anyway.  The netcode is absolutely atrocious. They saw the success of GGPO and tried to imitate with their own rollback netcode, but the execution failed horribly. You can try to hit confirm then get counter hit because the game rolled back the first hit. My favorite was when I got hit with an uppercut in the middle of a throw animation.  Even if you get a stable match, the inherent problems with the gameplay are still present. The game has 8 frames of input lag so 'offline will feel the same as online', but this is 8 frames of always-present input lag in addition to whatever input lag you get from being online. You literally cannot block some things on reaction. This leaves the game feeling sluggish, and reacting to moves or punishing is almost impossible. You will constantly input moves that will either come out late, resulting in a counter hit, or won't come out at all. Also get used to learning new meaty timings every single game, because they will be completely different depending on your opponent.  If you like fighting games then just wait, Capcom will fix this game eventually, Third Strike and Ultra are two of the greatest fighting games ever, but right now V is a complete ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• show.  Also, this game was made in 2016 and doesn't have a borderless option. If you attempt to launch it with borderless through steam it will most likely crash frequently.

Serious input lag, money grubbing devs and rage quitters are STILL a problem. Save your money and buy KOF 14 if you have a PS4, or just wait for Tekken 7 on PC.  Or you can be a man and go play Third Strike or Super Turbo on Fightcade for free.

Bugs that haven't been fixed since the beginning:  1. If your monitor is higher than 60hz its unplayable even if you turn on vsync or manually set the game to run at 60 frames. 2. Most fightsticks will not work with the game without 3rd party application support. 3. Matchmaking is broken and punishments are distributed at random to rage quitters and non-rage quitters.  I have played a lot of terrible console ports to pc and have extensive background in fixing issues that arise in that situation, this is one of two that are straight up unplayable.

There is so much wrong with how this game was delivered.  - Pathetic excuse for a story mode - No CPU Versus option or arcade mode - Must be online in order to earn experience, even in the offline game modes - Kind of a big deal, considering the servers still don't work and drop you within minutes - Losing connection to the spotty servers returns you to the main menu, including if you were in the middle of training mode, story mode, survival mode, or any other offline mode. - Lobbies don't work, and only allow for two players tops, despite the icons implying we'd have up to 6 people in a lobby. - No way to play with a friend without a lobby - No way to quickly rematch in a lobby, have to go through the entire proccess of loading into the main menu again, and load back into a match again. - Zero options to aquire alternate costumes post launch - Direct Input controllers are not supported. Only Xinput controllers work (For anyone who doesn't know, this means that only Xbox 360 controllers will work. PC controllers, PS4 Controllers, or any other kind of gamepad are not supported. This isn't an issue for me, but it's absolutley unbelievable). - Keyboard controls can't be rebound. - Keyboard is permenantly registered as 'Player 1', meaning that you can't play locally together with one person on keyboard and one person on controller. - The game runs BEST at your screen's native resolution. Anything less and the game lags (what???). - The game lags in windowed mode for seemingly no reason (I've got a R9 390, this is NOT a hardware issue). - Alt-Tab breaks the game view when you return and puts bars all over your screen. - The above three issues mean you can't do anything else on your system EXCEPT play the game.  The game itself is fun, but only if played offline with friends. This game is ridiculously barebones and calling it Early Access isn't a joke. The game reminds you that many of it's features will be ready in March as part of an update.  Don't buy. Go to your local meetups or tournaments and play there. You'll get a better experience and it'll cost you a fraction, if anything at all.

I have loved street fighter since SF2, but this has left me dissapointed and wanting. Severe frame rate drops, unpolished fighting system, stick to (ULTRA) Street Fighter IV. The graphics and flashy special effects seemed to be the focus in development of this title.

Lack of content could be forgiven. Lack of polish cannot. Why not to buy this game: - Barebones keyboard support: cannot bind keys to your liking (only a limited selection of keys is available), can't play 2 players on one keyboard, can't check the key bindings (keyboard keys are always displayed as XOne controller buttons) - No D-input devices support. If your controller is not X360/XOne you'll have to work around with joy2key and binding buttons to keyboard keys - No Steam UI support (cannot invite or join game, very clunky and slow to navigate ingame menus have to be used instead) - Menus/load screens (such as characters facing off before match) may drop to 30 fps even if your rig can run the match at stable 60. Game speed is relative to framerate, so if it drops to 30 you'll experience slow motion. This occurs on PCs that match recommended specs -Console crossplay is nigh impossible (tested PC to PC - 10/10 connection, PC - PS4 on the same connection - unplayable) -Invites to player lobbies often outright do not work (no response or 'lobby does not exist' message)  Aside from that general issues: - Barely any SP content - No option to decline matches (if you get paired with someone who lags you just have to suck it up and play even though you know you won't enjoy the match) - Characters models are detailed, but very unpolished (horrible hair clippings, even on character select screen and numerous cloth physics errors)  This game has been rushed so that this year's Capcom Pro Tour season can be played only in SFV. If you do not want to participate in the tournaments DO NOT BUY.

The launch of Street Fighter V was an unmitigated disaster. With my arcade stick hooked up and ready to go, I faced my first challenge on my road to becoming a world champion: getting past the User Agreement screen. The game would not respond to my joystick inputs, so figuring I had to pass the screen to get into an options menu and enable it, I tried using my keyboard to get past the legalese threshold guardian. The arrow keys worked, but hitting 'Enter' would not advance the game. I'm lucky enough to have a second arcade stick, so I plugged that in. No dice. The mouse fared no better, so I fell back on years of gaming experience and proceeded to press every key on the keyboard. Finally, I was making progress. Protip: it's 'B'.   This was the first stumbling block in a comedy of errors. Turns out neither fight stick I own is supported even though Windows certainly recognizes them as functional. Bold move for a fighting game. Then I got to witness the joys of launch day server problems: they didn't work, either. Granted this is unfortunately common, but Street Fighter V is a game with next to no fallback plan for when the online portion is out of commission. There are a few (very few) single player options, but if you're not connected to Capcom's servers you're not earning ‚Äúfight money‚Äù, the game's currency for buying future DLC characters and costumes. I say ‚Äúfuture‚Äù because right now the Store option is blacked out, promising to open at a later date. So what that fight money is actually worth... who knows? The game isn't interested in telling you. It's not interested in telling you many things, actually...   So, despite not racking up Capcom funny money, I decided to dive into the few options available to me, starting with the Story mode. You could easily confuse this to mean Arcade mode, but don't get your hopes up. What's on offer is almost hilariously awful. Almost. I've played enough fighting game stories at this point to appreciate some cheese, but Street Fighter V's Story Mode is offensively bad to the point I had to skip most of the ‚Äúcutscenes‚Äù. And by ‚Äúcutscenes‚Äù, I mean static, hand drawn illustrations that appear to drawn by a middle grade student who checked out a ‚ÄúHow to Draw Anime‚Äù book from the library. It's bad, and the story and dialogue aren't much better. Each fighter is tasked to complete roughly three one round fights, starting with full meters, in what has to be the easiest of Easy difficulty settings with no option to tweak any settings. This mode lasted all of an hour.   What caught my eye next was a Training mode that promised numerous different options to hone your skills. I adored the training mode in Street Fighter IV, so I was looking forward to hopping in and challenging myself to some combos. Nope. It's just a dummy AI mode where you can set the CPU to different states. No combo lists or actual training of any kind. There's not even a VS CPU mode, so all that was left on my plate was Survival, which is easily the strongest of the offline offerings. Here you fight through a set number of CPU opponents depending on your difficulty setting, and spend the points you earn through winning matches on ‚Äúsupplements‚Äù which range from health gains to offense, defense, and meter boosts. If you're trying to practice anything else besides health boosts kind of screw up the game, but it's better than nothing.   Days later, the servers seem to be somewhat functional so I've been playing Survival mode with Fight Requests turned on... because there's not a whole lot else to do in the game. Every now and then I even get to fight online, and sometimes it's playable. For a test I set aside an hour to gauge my success: Ranked requests on, all platforms, regions, skill levels. In that hour, I had a whopping one match come up against a fine fighter named PoopyPoopFarts. To the game's credit the match was very smooth. After that hour, another fight popped, but it was laggy to the point of unplayability and got disconnected after about thirty seconds. Going into straight Ranked matchmaking is painful, staring at a spinning wheel for three to ten minutes on average, and about two thirds of those games ran very poorly as well.   The core mechanics of Street Fighter V seem okay. I find them simple, but I'm not a hardcore fighting fanatic so any depth beyond generic strategies and spamming specials is lost on me, and it's too much to ask the game to actually teach you anything in-game, apparently. There are promises of a true Arcade mode, challenges, and loads of ‚Äúfree‚Äù content coming to Street Fighter V in the future, and who knows? Maybe this game will be a complete package someday down the line. As it is now, it feels rushed, unfinished, and outright broken in many cases. The problem with waiting for these updates is the game was released as a full priced product, and by the time those updates roll out there will be better, more complete games already released (there are already plenty), so I don't know who this game is for. Not me, anyway.
No Arcade Mode, No working multiplayer.

On older systems such as a first gen quad core with a 260GTX, the fights are perfectly playable in high res texture, med shadow and effects with the rest on low. Only catch is that part of the game menu, the whole storyboard, and life bars are all invisible due to a graphics overlay glitch. (this is just sheer laziness on the part of Capcom, with nothing to do with hardware capability.) With PC titles, there seems to be no such thing as lazy inefficient codes, just underpowered systems.  Speaking of laziness, the free-hand sketchbook cartoon style from the storyboard art just screams rush job and even then Capcom couldn't give us a complete arcade mode experience upon release, and it seems that we may be forced to buy what should have been integrated into the title as DLCs. At this point, aside from the graphical and online server bugs, the so called game is so stripped down that it should be called a demo.   There are definitely many torches and pitchforks at the doors of Capcom.

As of 04/05/2016:  - Horrible rollback (lag) for me in Japan, other games including SFIV and Guilty Gear Xrd work great - so it's not my connection, I'd say about 6/10 matches have some form of lag, sometimes really bad, other times very annoying - The in-game menus look rushed and some have spelling mistakes - The stats still don't work in player profiles - Country Flags still don't load in battle lounge search - One sided lag still exists - Sometimes you have to alt-tab in and out of the game to stop online lag/rollback from occuring - Rage quitting is punished better in games many years older than this - Battle lounges (lobbies) still aren't stable, searching for them sometimes results in a disconnect and I have to wait a few mins before I can search again - Matchmaking continues to pair rank 10,000+ players against super gold players (the matchmaking sucks) - Game still crashes/freezes at the results screen after matches quite often - Still no way to play multiple matches at a time in one lobby = 8 player lobbies are very boring, other games like Guilty Gear Xrd have had this for a long time - Still no region filtering in battle lounge search meaning I have to guess where a player is from based on their name, this is ridiculous, Street Fighter IV had region filtering in 2009... - Connection bars still often don't indicate connection quality, played someone with 5 bars in South Korea (from Japan) and had the worst rollback/lag I've ever experienced  So yeah as a fighting game in 2016 this is kind of a joke. This game feels like Early Access.  TL;DR - Wait until it's on sale and/or been patched more. I want to like this game but Capcom are making it difficult.

Earlier I've rated this review positively, hoping that it would improve. Sadly Capcom has brought disappointment after disappointment. PC community has always been big on modding, and of course they restricted it. I can understand why, but how they executed it is just awful. The best way to do implement it is to implement it the exact same way Techland did for Dying Light. There should be an option for modding. Where modders will only be able to play with modders, and not with PS4 and Vanilla Users. Sadly they don't see that. Instead they try releasing a Rootkit (which at most time is considered a backdoor for viruses.) Apparently they took it off to avoid legal trouble but the damage has already been done.   Now am I saying its a bad game? No. In fact, I love the game and still prefer it over other mainstream fighting games (Except for tekken and guilty gear). And it's helluva lot better than Mortal Kombat. But I can't say I recommend it. Or at least for full price. I would say this. It's a great game to start fighting games, but do yourself a favor. Just wait for a better rerelease of the game.   At that time, like always, the game would be fixed, everything would be present and you get your money's worth.

That being said, the fighting mechanics are definitely solid and great for those that are beginners. Like Ono-San said, easy to learn, difficult to master.  There is no arcade mode, survival mode doesn't have any real feel of progress to it like arcade mode, it just feels like something to do.  In versus mode, you cannot fight a CPU, only another human player. The story mode is more of a ‚Äúprologue‚Äù mode and there's no way to increase the difficulty since it is too easy, and that's coming from a novice. I haven't really tried the online mode because I know I'll get my butt kicked, but from what I read and heard, online performance is poor.  Simply put, I cannot recommend the game in it's current state, and neither are many review outlets, that's why they're holding off their full reviews until the game is complete.

Street Fighter V, at the state of its release, is an incomplete package that can't be justify by anyone, not even pro players. The tutorial itself is even more barebone than Mortal Kombat X and the Training is lackluster in terms of options. Acquiring colors from Solo Modes is almost impossible because if you get disconnected, you lose your entire progression and you can't earn any form of currency offline which means that this game is always-online! There's no Player vs. CPU, the Prologue Mode (the Story as of yet) is lacking in every respect (and I thought Killer Instinct was a bit disappointing). The graphics are on par with the PS3 and, worst of all, the game doesn't support all fightsticks without doing some tweaks. I love Street Fighter V as a game... As a product, it fails in the most important aspects!

I'm not sure how to structure this review, so I'll just list all the things wrong with this game. I preordered the game, and as an avid fan of fighting games, I really wanted to love it.  1. NO XINPUT SUPPORT. I need to use joy2key to play with my controller, by mapping my stick to the keyboard controls. The keyboard controls which I cannot change. This means that I cannot play with my friend, who typically play on keyboard, or have PS4 controllers, which also do not work natively. (Reminder, Skullgirls, a fighting game which you can get on sale for $1, instantly recognized my stick, as well as any other controller we threw at it.)  2. NO PUNISHING RAGE QUITTING. People can and will disconnect from you all the time, to avoid a loss. This is because Capcom has no way to tell who actually disonnected, due to their horrible netcode.  3. DLC IS A SCAM. We were very excited when this game was announced, as Capcom said they would be implementing a store in which you can buy DLC characters with in game currency, instead of forking over $20-$40 for a new edition. However, basically the only way to get enough of this in game currency to buy anything is by completing their extremely broken and boring 'survival mode' which takes the place of a proper arcade mode. Fortunately, PC users can cheat to complete survival, something which Capcom is helpless to prevent. Anyway, most of the DLC is only available for purchase with real money, so its almost a moot point.  Maybe check back in a year to see if Capcom has figured their game out, but this is an incredible waste of money, even on sale to be honest.

To begin this review, I would like to start off by saying that I am a tad biased as I have been a huge fan of the Steet Fighter games before this new iteration and am an avid supporter of the Fighting Game Community (FGC). I love fighting games and I have played most modern fighters (Street Fighter, Tekken, Smash 4, etc) in an effort to become well-trained and to, as the community so eloquently puts it, 'git gud.'   All of this being said, I cannot, just  cannot  recommend this game to anyone who is a casual player.   Street Fighter V, upon its initial release, lacked little to no content for roping in a new casual playerbase. That's strange considering that that was one of their main goals with SFV. Capcom wanted to bring in new players, competitive or not, to produce mass sales for the game and also perhaps expose the general public to fighting game tournaments as well. Those who weren't really interested in the competitive scene could slowly be introduced to Capcom Pro Tour (CPT) and perhaps even be molded to be competitive players. Capcom failed to do this, however, by not even giving the simplest of features such as CPU versus or even the classic arcade mode.   Every other aspect that recognizes the competitiveness of the game is completely fine and actually very well-made. The netplay can be a little wonky here and there, but other than that returning cast members have been reimagined in unique and exciting ways while some stayed pretty much the same. New original characters are fun and not too overbearing. And with future DLC characters, the roster is ever-expanding for at least the next few years.  All of this being said, I can't bring my heart to recommend this game to anyone who isn't looking to be competitive no matter how much time I put into it. The release was a mess and Capcom, almost 5 months later, are just now getting around to adding some solo modes to the game, including the story mode. There's also the lack of communication on their end (and in their defense they have gotten better at it), but I don't really blame them for that. That's more of a part of Japanese culture when it comes to video games, it seems.   Overall, for competitive players, the game is probably a solid 8/10. For casual players, I can't even really give it a score. All I can say is to stay away and give it a proper year or so to develop, maybe even just look for it when there's a price drop or a sale. If you're looking for some type of casual fighting game on PC, I'd recommend  Rivals or Aether,  a very fun Super Smash Bros. style game.

If you want to play the game purely against other players, go for it. Maybe you're into fighting games and want to practice for tournaments. Most people probably don't fall under that umbrella. This game will not be fun for the average user. - Unintuitive UI - CANNOT REMAP CONTROLS - DOES NOT READ PS3 FIGHTSTICKS/CONTROLLERS - Lack of on-time updates - Lack of decent arcade mode (all characters only fight 4 people max with poor scenes) - Survival is a waste of time against CPU with perfect reads  Even if you're into just the gameplay, there's things to be frustrated about too - Invite system is slow and tedious in custom rooms (does not use steam invites) - Training mode does not save your previous settings - Little over 1/5th of the roster requires you to play the terrible arcade modes or put hours into ranked - CANNOT REMAP BUTTONS - DOES NOT READ PS3 FIGHTSTICKS  I've around 20hrs on it at the time of writing and am only putting more just to play with a friend. Not worth the 60-70 CAD I paid for it when I've over 85hrs on Blazblue and I bought that for 32 CAD. Look elsewhere for a fun fighting game you can play with friends.

Keep in mind, Capcom is the same company that put on-disc DLC for SFxTekken to milk you for all your money, and now they are doing it again charging you $60 for an alpha-build that requires additional purchases of DLC characters and stages that should already be in the game in the first place. That's right, you are actually paying for STAGES now too, and people still defend this company.   Ranked matchmaking is just unacceptable... takes way too long to find a match and it usually connects you with people halfway across the world in an unplayable teleporting lagfest. You also don't lose points for ragequitting in a ranked match, which is beyond pathetic and completely nullifies the point of a ranked system and leaderboard. Imagine a competitive game where you can just quit a match right before you lose and not be penalized, yeah it just doesn't happen... only in this cheap unfinished product masquerading under the charade of being an e-sports game. The actual gameplay is decent, but it is also lackluster because the hard one-frame combos, vortexes, setups, and mixups from USF4 were completely pruned from the game to make it more accessible to new players.   If you find this game for anywhere between $1-$10, buy it and try it out. Otherwise, save your money and stop rewarding Capcom for being one of the worst companies in the industry for the last decade.

Story mode is not fun, not fleshed out and horribly written. Survival mode is not fun, an hour of easy fights then the final fight has difficulty +1000%. Online is pointless unless you've spent 100+ hours with your character of choice. All the characters look like dolls with barebones facial animations. Couldn't stand the music so I muted it, which thankfully is an option. Where is Arcade mode? I'm very impressed with the voice acting though, Japanese and English, spot on, well done. The gameplay is beautiful, plenty of options on how to engage fights, does not feel clunky or slow, no one is overpowered (yet). The community is helpful, engaged, and will try their best to teach you to teach yourself to get better at the game. Overall not worth the full price tag at it's current level of content (unless you're just playing online), promised future content a plus at no additional price tag (unless you want it instantly), 5/10, an average game for your average gamer.

I don't want to have to not recommend this game but in it's current state, unless you really love fighting games, it's really not even close to worth full price.  Pros: -One of the most solid fighting games in terms of mechanics on the market. It's a bit of a departure from 4 but depending on what you want from the game that can be a good or a bad thing. -Decent character roster. With the exception of F.A.N.G. who seems to have a really ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• moveset (demonstrated by the fact that in 6 hours I have not fought one single person using him online) the rest of the characters old and new are fun and varied. -The optimisation on my PC at least seems excellent. The game can hold 60fps with no noticable dips with all settings maxed on my i5 and GTX670. -Being able to unlock future characters which would otherwise be DLC through in game currency.  Cons: -Fight Money is not called Bison Dollars. -There is no store currently available for me to spend my 200,000 Fight Moneys in. -The story modes available for each character are frankly pathetic. When it was anounced to be a mode comparable to MK9/10's story modes which were a good few hours long each with nice in-engine cutscenes and all the fancy trimmings I got excited. What you actually get when you begin a 'Story' is a well drawn still image for a minute or so while one of the voice actors says a few lines, then another still image for another minute or two with some more lines, then another, repeat ad nauseum for every single 'cutscene' for every character. I got bored after the first two and just skipped them all for every single character which left me with 2-3 fights for each character taking me a total of 48 minutes to complete the story mode. Before you say that doesn't count because I skipped cutscenes, I say a collection of 30 still images is not what was advertised. -The netcode while better, is still not great. Even having restricted my search options to only the most compatible connections available I still get matches with opponents teleporting around me, random slowdown mid-match and depending on the time of day wait times up to several minutes to even find a game. -The servers flat out were not working on launch. This is unacceptable for a AAA game and even though it is the norm it leaves a bitter taste.  -PC version is not compatible with any PS3/4/non-xbox sticks. This was a huge disappointment when I plugged in my Qanba Q1 and it simply didn't function. There are programs you can use to fix it such as x360ce but with probably the biggest and most historic fighting game franchise in the world you simply shouldn't have to! -The game is generally lacking in other game modes. While to my knowledge SF games generally have at least a few different options for minigames and different things to do, in SFV there is no challenge mode, no minigames, you are limited to versus, story and a 30 match endurance/time attack mode.  Basically the whole game feels like they put time into the actual fighting, but everything else is pretty terrible and feels very cheap.

Game is ok-ish.  Season pass + game ($80 retail, $60 with steam discount) grants you the extra characters that they will 'eventually' release (so far they have announced ~8 and released 4 to the initial roster of 16) and that's it. Without season pass the amount of grind you have to do to buy the characters is considerable.  They now added the cinematic story mode which is about 2-3 hours of entertainment. it is fun. Worth $10-15 of the price (it is free). It is a step in the good direction for Capcom.  You will have to buy costumes with fight money or real money. You cannot buy ALL costumes with fight money (some are premium and currently only purchasable with real money -- and this is bad!). Very few stages, (8 maybe) and they have released a couple more -- one of them a daylight version of an existing one -- that you will need to spend currency on to get.  And all their 3D models clip :( but that's a minor annoyance.  If you don't care about that, then feel free to buy the game - it IS fun and mechanics are ok. Otherwise it seems rather expensive to have to pay extra for 'premium skins' considering the amount of money you dumped initially, even if you decide to not buy the season pass.

One of my biggest disappointments in gaming. SFV lacks classic arcade mode, what means the only option while you wait for a an human opponent is to play survival mode, which isn¬¥t great fun.  Gameplay completely favours offensive play, so hundreds of players who enjoy defensive play will not get any enjoyment. Blocking is punished really hard with a system that will transform all blocked damage into effective damage once you get hit once. Just look online for some videos of pros playing it, you see this clearly. Defensive players get smashed by offensive players even with a big skill gap between them.  I think this is what Capcom meant with the 'that both beginners and veterans can enjoy' in the description. Button mashing is, for the first time, effective in a SF game.  I wanted to enjoy it. I grew up playing this series, but simply can¬¥t find enjoyment in SFV.

Capcom obviously doesn't care about this game. $60 for a contentless 'game', with barely-functional netplay the likes of which hasn't been seen since Guilty Gear Accent Core Plus, and Capcom has the audacity to try to charge people more money for their piecemeal product. They can claim all they want that everything can be unlocked for free, but the system in place makes that an impossibility without grinding for thousands of hours.  The actual fighting system is a major step backwards. Everyone can agree Focus Attack was a mistake (and a shoddy knockoff of GG's Roman Cancel), but now there is a grand total of two defensive options that have any amount of reliability whatsoever. What is to be done when there is no counterplay once put on the defense? Nothing, apparently.  The graphics are nothing special.  The balancing is sort of there, at least, in the same way that Smash can be sort of considered balanced.  I guess if you like spamming throws and having only maybe 3 to 4 useful moves per character, this is the game for you. It also heavily favors 50/50s, 33/33/33s, and even 25/25/25/25s, so even the most unskilled players can crush people as long as they make their opponents guess wrong.   If you want to play something GOOD instead, play Guilty Gear Xrd.  2/10 for at least trying to be 3rd Strike without any of the fun.

While I have never wrote a bad review for a game, this will be my first. I am looking back at street fighter 4. A game that had lots of Offline content you could play by yourself and an excellent online environment.  THE GOOD   So lets start with the good in this game. Fighting wise everything seems really tight and refined. There is quite a bit of depth and a long road to mastery for the characters. I like all of them, they all look absolutely awesome. Basically at it's foundation it's a rock solid fighting game. Visual effects are very nice, Hit boxes seem to be fair. Inputs are precise, although take getting used to from other fighting games. Moves in them selves are easy to do. It gets much harder when you string them together, which is part of where the depth comes from.  The characters seem quite varied and so far balanced. I really have no complaints for the actual 'fighting' in the game.   THE BAD   The servers are just horrible. They have crashed quite a bit. Which you may say, that's fine, I'll just play offline instead. Well here is where things begin to suck. So first off any offline activity that rewards Exp/fight money ie Story/Survival. Will no longer help you progress your account as all rewards gains of such nature are disabled. Considering what I've heard that some costumes (story mode ones) cost 40,000 fight money and new characters cost 100,000 each. I'd say you are missing out on a lot.  It gets EVEN better. Say you are playing survival mode right? You are just killin it and you are just about to beat it. Well lol guess what the servers just went down. So that means it will rip you out of that mode and made everything you just did all for not. I found that to be extremely frustrating especially as a relatively new player. I never got into street fighter 4 simply because I had that soul calibur addiction. That said the abysmall amount of single player content just sucks.  I like to be competitive but at the same time I'd like more bang for my buck. Most games have story mode. Street fighter's story mode is a joke. 2-4 rounds at max. By that I mean say you pick ryu. You fight chun li ONE round, you win, then you fight ken or something 1 round. You win, end of story. It's that stupid. Why even add it?   The tutorial is garbage. If you haven't ever played street fighter it is going to give you part of the basics. It doesn't tell you how to use EX version of moves, there is no explanation for the effects of certain moves, nothing. So it's not very beginner friendly. I get that it's street fighter 5 (or whatever number in the series) That said there are still new comers and it's quite nice to have a good tutorial or guide somewhere within the game. Even if it is all written with some screen caps. It'd be nice.   The shop is close until march meaning you can't buy anything. No skins, no titles, nothing. That would be cool and all if maybe we got something other than some alternative colors or were allowed to buy the skins from the story mode which already exist and can be seen in the game.  If you don't have a friend in the physical realm who comes over and plays games with you/ a solid internet connection. Don't even bother with this game. There is barely anything for offline play. You can't even play versus against a bot. You are only limited to another person or by playing bots in survival mode. Survival mode is fun... but it's not going to be 2 weeks fun let alone a month. Challenge mode is also not available til march   So let's get to the online portion  Matchmaking takes forever. I mean a long long long time. Battle lounge.... seems like why is there an option to join when every option is either FULL, No longer exists, Disconnected It'd be so much nicer if you could have casual match ups just feed you matches with the option for another round if you want to. That way you are out there experiencing many different playstyles and getting more matches.   As it is now. I'd call this game unfinished. I'd give it a 20$ value for what it is now. I'll change my review if/when it improves in the future. Til now I'm quite salty over my 60$ purchase for what I see as an incomplete game.  If I were to look at games I enjoyed playing (fighters) It'd of been the soul calibur series, blazblue, and tekken. At least I could get a lot of matches quickly and the online was good enough I had fun (blazblue having flawless online in my experience)

This is a full retail game with on disk DLC (stages, colors, costumes). You can theoretically earn these items, but they're locked behind a massive time sink grind system that would put most MMOs to shame. In addition the game has massi e unpatched issues such as input latency attached to vsync, poor connection balancing resulting in extreme rollbacks during matches, and a complete lack of dInput support, meaning that PS4 controllers (required for the only other port of this game) arent compatible with the PC release.  MOST IMPORTANTLY this latest patch installs a driver that essentially acts as a root kit on your computer. If you have SFV installed, potentially anyone can use it to take complete control of your PC. To get ric of it, you have to delete capcom.sys in your system32 directory.

Played it for a good while. I really tried to love it. Gameplay is stellar and character design is so gorgeous... but everything else about it, from the lack of features, ridiculous inefficiency in loading times and Capcom's business practices and horiffic handling of the game just drags it down into the muck. Capcom's like your drug addicted uncle coming out of rehab. You think their finally done with their bad habits and maybe you can even trust them around the kids until they revert back to their old ways and start asking you for more cash. Then sale your tv on craigslist if you say no.  The games performance is... meh. Not bad, most pc's will get the job done but after coming from SF4 it's pretty underwhelming. The games performance dropped compared to it's betas and from what i've seen there was no reason for it. No graphic improvements from beta just doesn't perform as well for some reason (maybe they have something else running in the background we don't know about). Although for a rushed game on the unreal engine 4 it still performs better than I thought it would... In case it wasn't clear, i'm not a fan of the UE4 lol.  There are lot of good ideas here that I would like other fighting games to follow suit on. Like not locking new characters behind pay walls, actually letting you unlock them and simply make money off cosmetics. Not forcing you to buy the same game for an updated version. The problem is some good ideas are being executed poorly and i'm afraid devs will look at sfv sales and think sticking to the old ways of paid versions of the same game is the safe route that gamers want.  Overall it's still a decent fighting game even if it does feel barebones. Although they really need to give characters more tools. Not even just v mechanics I mean just more special moves in general. This game is the most boring Ryu has ever been, ibuki was ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• of her specials, Juri lost a bunch tools and gets a bootleg chun flip kick. Poor Gief doesn't even have a green hand.  I won't bore you to go through it's other problems, you can find rants about them anywhere on the fourms or other reviews.    Should you buy SFV?    Sure if you're a big fan of Street Fighter and really wanna play this, but to everyone else no unless you've played and got sick of every other fighting game. SFV is not a bad game but I feel other fighters are putting in more effort than capcom.   I'm not mad at you capcom for pawning off my t.v for a quick buck, just disappointed and I know you're better than this. I'm sure sfv's headed in the right direction but until I know your bad habits are gone for good i'm not trusting you around the kids.

Content has gotten better after a gazillion patches, but unless you are hopelessly addicted to this game and playing online 25 hours a day, you're gonna have to pay for every single thing that should have been there at launch, after you already paid 60 freaking bucks for the game.  The fighting mechanics feel great, but there aren't many (simple attacks, short combos and very few additional mechanics) and the game is so freaking fast that anticipation and reaction are far more difficult than rushing down like a madman. The pace of this game makes it play more like the turbo modes of previous Street Fighters cranked way up, and I vastly prefer the more restrained pace of Super SF2, USFIV or Alpha 3 in normal speed.  The way it is now, it feels like an airdash gatling fighter but without the long and flashy combos (or the means to break out of them). The end result is a game in which things happen too fast and then they are also over far too fast. It feels chaotic, like there is very little rhyme or reason outside of executing very short combos and varying strategies semi-randomly at breakneck speed.  If I want fast, I'll play something like Marvel VS Capcom. Street Fighter to me is at its best when its slower and much more cerebral, and that's not what you're gonna get here.
